 I. THE ENERGY SECTOR A. THE MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT 1.1 A Country Economic Report was distributed to the Board of Executive Directors on July 7, 1994. In 1993, Kazakstan adopted and began to implement a comprehensive structural reform program aimed at moving the country towards a market economy. Although considerable progress was made under the program in the privatization of significant segments of the economy as well as in price and financial reforms, macroeconomic developments remained largely determined by the behavior of inherited structures. In particular, unrestructured enterprises, insulated from competitive or regulatory pressures for efficient performance, proved unable to respond to liberalized market forces and continued to incur large losses and to generate large inter-enterprise short-term indebtedness to finance these losses. Faced with the prospect of sharp declines in production as result of the increasing insolvency of key sectors in the economy, the Government was compelled to periodically refinance these enterprises' net working capital requirements through monetary expansion. These refinancing operations undermined the Government's tight monetary policies and fuelled inflation. 1.2 To remove the structural constraint on its efforts to restore stability and foster growth, the Government launched an Anti-Crisis Program in July 1994. The program aimed at accelerating the pace of enterprise restructuring and deepening the program of market reforms and featured measures to: (i) speed up the privatization program; (ii) impose greater financial discipline on banks and enterprises; (iii) remove impediments to competitive pricing arising from monopolistic domestic market structures and restrictions on external trade; (iv) remove institutional barriers to the exit of non-viable firms and the entry of new firms; and (v) strengthen the social safety net. The Bank provided support to the implementation of this program with a Structural Adjustment Loan (Ln 3900-KZ) which was approved by the Board of Executive Directors on June 8, 1995. 1.3 The energy sector is central to the process of transforming Kazakstan's economy. First, structural reforms in the sector are a sine qua non for reform of the industrial sector. Currently, the energy sector accounts for an estimated 32% of industrial output, 30% of industrial employment and 8% of formal employment in the economy. The energy sector has been beset with slumping production in the oil subsector, excess capacity and employment in the coal subsector, deteriorating quality of service provision in the heat and power subsector and, in general, inadequate cash generation to finance adequate levels of both maintenance expenditures and replacement investments. In sum, the sector is being progressively de-capitalized. The following factors have been, until recently, at the root of the sector's problems: (i) low domestic energy prices; (ii) low prices, largely unrelated to world market levels, for exports to the country's traditional markets; (iii) major transport constraints on the country's ability to diversify export markets; and (iv) inadequate pressures and incentives for organizations to be commercial. These constraints would need to be relieved if the sector is to be economically efficient and financially viable. In addition to its direct contribution to economic activity, the sector also plays a critical role in the country's well-developed and highly energy-intensive mining and metallurgical subsectors. These subsectors currently account for about 50% of the country's hard currency exports and both their economic viability and future export competitiveness depend critically on reforms in the energy sector.
 2 1. The Energy Sector 1.4 Second, the energy sector, particularly the oil subsector, represents the country's most promising source of exports and economic growth in the medium term. Energy exports represented about 40% of the country's total exports in 1994. With the level of developed and producing reserves and the current pipeline of approved foreign investments in the sector, oil production could feasibly be doubled by 2003 from under 1% of proven reserves (17 million tons in 1995) to close to 2% of proven reserves (40 million tons per year) and net crude oil exports increased from 5 million tons to about 25 million per year. The implications of such an increase in exports for the economy are enormous: oil export revenues would increase by US$2.0 billion and incremental Government fiscal revenues would amount to around US$800 million per annum, equivalent to about 35% of the Government's current (1995) budget. However, realizing this potential would require stabilizing production from existing producing fields, and creating the transport capacity to export oil production to markets with world market-related oil prices. 1.5 Finally, unlike many other sectors of the economy, the prospects for attracting foreign investments into the energy sector and freeing domestic resources for use in other sectors are good, provided that an appropriate framework of laws and regulations are in place and, in the case of the subsectors with non-tradeable outputs, that macroeconomic conditions also are favorable to the earning and repatriation of adequate returns to investors' investments. 1.6 The Government has made great progress, particularly over the last 18 months, in formulating policies to address most of the above issues. The key policy measures already in place and the outstanding issues for further action are enumerated in the following sections. B. ENERGY RESOURCES ENDOWMENT 1.7 Kazakstan has an enormous endowment of energy resources. The country's total recoverable reserves of oil, gas and coal are estimated at 13.0 billion tons of oil equivalent (toe) or 722 toe per capita, ranking it among the top ten countries in the world in terms of per capita energy resources. Coal is the dominant resource in terms of discovered recoverable reserves with delineated reserves of about 22 billion tons, equivalent to about 10 billion tons of oil equivalent (toe). The coal reserves are concentrated in 30 major occurrences located around the north- eastern city of Karaganda. 1.8 Recoverable reserves of oil and gas are estimated at 2.1 billion tons (16 billion barrels) and 1.6 trillion cubic meters (1.3 billion toe equivalent) respectively, and are concentrated in the western part of the country around the Caspian Sea. The prospects for significant additional discoveries of oil and gas are good. Kazakstan contains or is straddled by six major petroleum basins, some segments of which have not been explored intensively in the past. Undiscovered recoverable oil and gas reserves in these basins have been assessed to be at least as large as the present level of reserves. 1.9 In addition to coal and hydrocarbon resources, the country has substantial hydropower resources with an estimated hydropower potential of 160 trillion KWh of which about 60 trillion KWh could be technically developed. Only about 10% of this technically feasible hydropower resource has been developed. Aside from its base of natural resources, Kazakstan also has a well- developed base of energy transformation industries supplying a significant proportion of the domestic requirement for final energy resources.
 1. The Energy Sector 3 C. DOMESTIC ENERGY DEMAND AND PRODUCTION 1.10 Total demand for primary energy in Kazakstan is estimated at 66 million toe in 1993 compared to domestic production of about 77 million toe, leaving a large net exportable surplus of primary energy resources of about 11 million toe (Annex 1.1). The demand for final energy amounted to about 52 million toe in 1993. However, in contrast to the surplus in primary energy trade and reflecting the location of significant processing capacity in the neighboring countries, trade in final energy resources resulted in a deficit of about 2 million toe. 1.11 Energy production has been characterized by large declines over recent years. Coal production, accounting for about 60% of total primary energy production, has fallen by 23% since 1991 with much of the decline attributable to a sharp drop in export demand from Russia. Due to structural changes in the Russian coal market, coal exports are unlikely to increase unless alternative export markets can be found. Owing to the relatively high cost of long-distance coal transport by rail, it is unlikely that significant and viable alternative markets for coal displaced from the Russian market could be found. Crude oil and condensate production in 1995 had fallen by about 23% since reaching a peak of 27 million tons in 1991, mostly as a result of increasing backlogs in the workover of wells as a result of the straitened financial position of the oil enterprises. Most of the decline in oil production has been absorbed by reductions in exports. Finally, the total domestic production of petroleum products has declined by 33% since 1990 both as a result of supply constraints arising from progressively more intermittent supplies of imported crude oil and reduced demand. 1.12 Notwithstanding the sharp reduction in overall economic activity since 1988, domestic energy consumption has remained stagnant. Kazakstan, like most of the countries of the FSU, is characterized by highly intensive and inefficient use of energy. With a current gross domestic use of primary energy of about 4400 kilograms of oil equivalent (koe) per capita, the domestic consumption of energy is around 25% greater than that in the major economies of Western Europe with per capita incomes about four times as great as that of Kazakstan (Annex 1. 2). The scope for rationalizing energy use is great, and the Government, supported by a number of bilateral agencies, has started on a comprehensive program of energy audits and conservation promotion. Increases in the relative price of energy are an important instrument for curtailing demand and for providing a financial incentive for conservation. However, their impact has yet to be felt mainly because most relative energy prices have only been recently increased to a substantial proportion of world market parity prices and the switch over of energy-intensive industries to more efficient energy use and management demands (i) considerable financial strictures beyond that currently imposed on major energy-using enterprises; and (ii) financial resources not available to large energy-using enterprises. D. ENERGY RESOURCES DEVELOPMENT: THE REGIONAL CONTEXT 1.13 Kazakstan's energy sector was developed as an important component of a highly integrated regional energy market spanning southern Russia and the republics of Central Asia. In particular, the energy systems of the country are regionally distinct and more closely integrated physically with those of neighboring countries than with each other. The integration of Kazakstan's energy sector with that of its neighbors has resulted in a complex pattern of energy trade under which (i) crude oil is exported from the main areas of production in western Kazakstan to the Volga and Urals regions of Russia and imported in eastern Kazakstan from West
 4 I. The Energy Sector Siberia; (ii) the country is a substantial importer of petroleum products although it produces enough crude oil and has sufficient refining capacity to be self-sufficient with appropriate investments in refinery upgrading and crude oil transport links; (iii) raw gas is exported from western Kazakstan to Russia and processed gas is imported from Russia and Central Asia; (iv) the country is served by three non-connected electricity grids that are integral parts of regional power systems in Russia or Central Asia; and (v) large amounts of coal are both imported and exported. 1.14 For much of the period since independence, the country has had to cope with two adverse consequences of this regional legacy: (i) low export prices and uncertain costs and security of supply of key imported energy resources; and (ii) constraints on the level of production and on the financial performance of its energy sector as a result of market conditions in other parts of the region. In particular, the amount of energy resources, especially oil, that the country can export outside the FSU at higher world market parity prices is severely restricted while, within the FSU, it has been constrained to exporting its energy resources at prices significantly lower than the price of energy imports. For example, the country ran a substantial trade surplus with the FSU in energy of about 1 1.0 million toe in physical terms in 1993. However, this surplus translated into a monetary trade deficit of about US$35 million equivalent, largely as the result of huge differentials in the prices of imports and exports. 1.15 Following many past attempts at resolving the issue of trade prices and security of energy supplies mainly through inter-republican trade agreements, the Government's strategic focus has shifted increasingly to: (i) creating the domestic infrastructure (crude oil pipeline and electricity transmission lines) to achieve supply security and self-sufficiency where such investments are demonstrably viable given the expected incidence and costs of supply disruptions; (ii) encouraging commercial alliances between domestic and Russian oil enterprises to promote trade on mutually beneficial terms; and (iii) developing alternative crude oil pipelines for the transport of Kazakstan oil to seaports for export to international markets. This shift in strategy is appropriate given both the importance of developing stable and equitable trading relations with the country's major trade partner and the need to diversify trading options and reduce the risk of energy dependence on one trading partner. E. DOMESTIC ENERGY PRICING 1.16 The Government has allowed substantial increases in energy prices since independence. The system of administered prices for energy inherited from the Union was substantially liberalized in March 1994 to allow both the intervals and magnitudes of price increases for all energy supplies, except utility services to households, to be determined by producers subject to maximum allowable margins over operating costs. Further liberalization in the system of price- setting was introduced in November and December 1994 when, under a series of ministerial decrees, the system of prescribed margins over costs as a basis of pricing-setting was abolished for crude oil, natural gas, and petroleum products (at the ex-refinery level). Under the revised price-setting system, the relevant energy enterprises were granted greater autonomy to set prices subject only to prior review and approval by the Price Committee of the Anti-Monopoly Commission. In April 1, 1995, the Government removed crude oil and petroleum product pricing ex-refinery from the direct oversight of the Price and Anti-Monopoly Committees. In September 1995, crude oil and petroleum product prices were fully liberalized. These actions reflect the recognition by the Government that, in cases where energy producers and suppliers do not enjoy
 1. The Energy Sector 5 a natural monopoly or structural changes could be effected to introduce competition where it is absent, the Government's involvement in price setting is both unnecessary and undesirable. Additional measures taken in the oil industry to reinforce competitive pricing include the elimination of export quotas on petroleum products. With respect to the power sector, electricity prices continue to be administered. However, the Government plans to reform electricity pricing to allow the electricity utility to generate enough profits to finance, through internal cash generation, a pre-determined proportion of its capital expenditure and maintenance plan, subject to review and approval of the allowable margin and the utility's cost structure by the Price and Anti-Monopoly Committee. The Government is currently undertaking studies to determine the options for restructuring the industry and putting in place a pricing system that would allow for the differentiation of tariffs for different classes of consumers in order to better reflect the cost of supply of electricity to such classes of consumers. F. SECTOR ORGANIZATION 1.17 Until June 1994, two ministries shared administrative responsibility for the sector along functional lines. The Ministry of Energy and Fuel Resources (MEFR) had oversight responsibilities for all energy producing and related activities while the Ministry of Geology (MG) was (and continues to be) responsible for all exploration activities within the sector. MEFR was created in early 1992 to take over the responsibilities of the former Union-wide Ministries of Power, of Oil Industry and of Gas Industry in Kazakstan. The sector operating entities, formerly managed by the state concerns and committees under the Union-wide Ministries, were reorganized into ten product-based holding groups under the direct administrative control of MEFR. Each holding group had responsibility for determining appropriate production targets and monitoring performance, vetting investment proposals and capital expenditures, and formulating policy for and overseeing the conduct of international trade and foreign investment transactions. Voluntary associations of regionally-based related operating and service entities (Production Associations) within each holding group were responsible for the (i) coordination of operating relations between the entities; (ii) monitoring of the performance of members and the management of reporting to the parent holding groups; (iii) provision of specialized management and technical services to the constituent entities; (iv) international procurement, exporting and the management of hard currency revenues; and (v) allocation of investment resources among entities. The MG, which was a long-established republican ministry, remained responsible for the exploration of hydrocarbons, and other fuels and minerals. In June 1994, MEFR was split into two ministries: the Ministry of Oil and Gas (MOG) with responsibility for petroleum activities; and the Ministry of Power and Coal with administrative oversight over coal production and power generation, transmission and distribution. 1.18 Other Govermment agencies with significant oversight or policy roles in the sector include: (i) the Ministry of the Environment and Bio-resources which monitors compliance with enviromnental regulations in ongoing operations and investment plans; (ii) the State Committee on Foreign Capital utilization in the Ministry of Finance, which vets and approves all proposed investments with foreign financing participation; and (iii) the State Property Committee (SPC) in which is vested the state's ownership of sector assets and control over the disposition of assets. 1.19 Since the initial post-independence reorganization of the sector to transfer supervisory responsibilities for the sector from Moscow-based to national institutions, the Government has made considerable progress at the policy level in clarifying the mandate of the sectoral holding
 6 1. The Energy Sector groups and starting the process of organizational reform in the sector. All the holding groups were transformed by a series of Presidential Decrees issued in late 1993 into legally autonomous enterprises with the exercise of ownership rights over sector enterprises under their supervision transferred to them by SPC. The holding companies were charged with the incorporation of entities under their control as joint-stock companies, the preparation of plans for the restructuring of sector activities to promote efficient operations, and the formulation and implementation of plans for the selective divestiture of part of their equity interest in sector entities to the public and foreign strategic investors. 1.20 Progress in implementing the restructuring of the sector has been slow. Structurally, the sector organizational arrangements inherited from the FSU have only recently started to be substantially reformed. The sector continues to be organized largely into integrated or related entities with multiple supervisory tiers. The demarcation of responsibilities between supervisory tiers is unclear, obscuring responsibility for performance. Competition in the provision of goods and services, where feasible, is limited and the existing structure promotes a strong incentive for cross-subsidization of related entities within regional or national groups. In addition to weak market pressures for efficient performance, an effective regulatory framework for sector operations that are natural monopolies has only recently started to emerge. Given this institutional backdrop, selective but large operating subsidies to sector entities and relatively easy access to financing for operations (mostly involuntarily extended arrears on receivables), the predominant performance objective in the sector is still centered around the level of production, whether its level or mix is efficient and profitable or not. At present, the sector is largely immune from both the economic and financial pressures necessary to motivate it to perform efficiently. 1.21 The Government fully recognizes that its strategy of effecting structural change through the holding companies has contributed to slowing the process of structural change: the holding groups have limited incentives to oversee radical change in the present organizational arrangements, have no powers to effect supportive policy changes and have multiple and possibly conflicting mandates. In the light of this, the Government has taken initiatives to breakup the holding companies and to restructure and privatize parts of the sector using independent outside advisors and Government agencies independent of the holding companies. G. ENERGY AND THE ENVIRONMENT 1.22 The production and inefficient use of energy resources has contributed immensely to the degradation of the environment and a high incidence of avoidable occupational ailments. Energy production and supply activities in Kazakstan are characterized by a large number of environmentally unsound practices: (i) environmental controls are lacking or ineffectual in coal and uranium mining; (ii) oil production involves extensive and wasteful flaring of associated gas, widespread spillage of oil and improper disposal of produced fluids; and (iii) power generation involves the large scale use of high-ash and low-grade coal and large volumes of ash-handling and disposal without adequate emission control systems. In addition, the absence of financial incentives for the efficient use of energy, and the concomitant widespread use of energy inefficient and obsolete technologies in industry coupled with the priority given to heavy and energy-intensive industries resulted in an energy production strategy that contributed to both the wasteful use and accelerated depletion of key energy resources.
 1. The Energy Sector 7 1.23 Reversing this legacy of environmental degradation would require: (i) significant investments in remediating past and reducing future damage to the enviromnent; (ii) price reforms to promote efficient use and production of energy resources; and (iii) the strengthening of environmental standards and the systems for monitoring and promoting compliance with established standards. The Government is making steady progress with respect to the latter two issues. Progress in restructuring technological practices and remediating past environmental damage is likely to be slow given the present constraints on resources. H. THE BANK'S ROLE IN THE SECTOR 1.24 The Bank's strategy in Kazakstan is to support policies and investments that promote economic recovery and growth and social development within a stable macroeconomic environment. The focus of the Bank's strategy is on restoration of the country's productive capacity, improved public sector management, and strengthening of the social safety net. 1.25 The energy sector is a central element in this strategy: the efficient and secure production and supply of energy from the huge base of discovered but undeveloped as well as developed energy resources is critical to economic recovery and is the country's most promising source of growth in exports revenue in the medium term. 1.26 Owing to the huge capital and foreign exchange requirements of the energy sector in general and the petroleum subsector in particular, rational investment, taxation and pricing policies and effective systems of corporate governance and regulation are essential to its efficient development. Accordingly, the Bank's energy sector strategy aims at: (i) encouraging and assisting the Government to develop an appropriate legal and institutional environment to enhance the efficiency and cash-generating capacity of energy sector entities and attract foreign direct investments and financing; and (ii) supporting, through lending for investments and technical assistance, selective but critical initiatives to stem the decline in output, improve the efficiency of operations of existing sector entities, relieve infrastructure constraints on the sector's access to viable domestic and export markets and act as a catalyst to attract foreign investment and promote reform in sector institutional arrangements. 1.27 The initial focus of the Bank's sector assistance strategy is the petroleum subsector. This early emphasis reflects four factors: (i) the subsector's substantial potential for a rapid initial increase in production; (ii) the potential for a rapid increase in exports, foreign exchange earnings and the subsector's contribution to Government fiscal revenues; (iii) the early foreign investor interest in the development and rehabilitation of the huge discovered resources in the subsector and in the exploration of the country's highly promising petroleum prospects; and (iv) the need for early attention to resolving critical domestic policy and oil transport issues to enable the subsector's production potential to be fully realized both in the medium and long term. 1.28 The Bank's petroleum subsector strategy is being implemented through an inter-related program of investment lending and technical assistance operations supported by elements of the Bank's first structural adjustment operation in the country. 1.29 Investment Lending Operations. The focus of the Bank's investment operation in the sector has been the Uzen oil field. Uzen is the largest fully-developed and producing field in Kazakstan with remaining proven reserves of about 100 million tons or 750 million barrels (paras
 8 1. The Energy Sector 4.2 and 5.6). However, a growing and large backlog of well workover and maintenance of field facilities that has been accumulating since 1989 has led to a sharp, premature and accelerating rate of decline in its annual oil production from about 5% in 1988-1989 to 25% in 1994-1995 (para. 4.15). The continuation of the average rate of decline since 1989 will result in the cessation of economic operations in the field by 2002 with about 90 million tons of oil unrecovered. The rehabilitation of the field is potentially viable but, given the degree of deterioration of its operating assets and facilities, will cost an estimated US$0.9 billion (para 5.5). An estimated US$0.2 to US$0.3 billion of this rehabilitation requirement will need to be raised from external sources, assuming an efficiently managed rehabilitation program. 1.30 The key policy and institutional constraints on the viable rehabilitation of a field like Uzen were identified during the early stages of the Bank's involvement in the sector and the preparation of a possible package of assistance to Uzen under the Rehabilitation Loan (KZ-PA- 8509). Specific actions and programs were designed to address these constraints and were incorporated in a Petroleum Technical Assistance (PTA) Project (Ln 3744-KZ) and the Structural Adjustment Loan (Ln 3900-KZ) (paras 1.32 to 1.34). However, as a mature oil-producing operation, the Uzen field faces a number of other problems in attracting the external financing that is critical to its rehabilitation: (i) extensive environmental contamination of the field against which no past provision for remediation has been made and for which the future liability for remediation is unknown; (ii) an inefficient organizational structure with substantial overstaffing, extensive internal cross-subsidization of non-viable activities, weak management and financial controls and ambiguous commercial mandate and powers; (iii) limited availability of credible information on the condition of wells and the producibility of the remaining oil reserves from the existing stock of wells. In addition there is no well-organized process or experienced domestic capacity for soliciting investment interest in established on-going oil field operations. Reflecting these constraints, the Government's past attempts at attracting investments to the field have been unsuccessful. 1.31 Given this background, the Bank's role in the Uzen rehabilitation program has been to help the Government to (i) establish that the rehabilitation of the field is viable using methods and yardsticks familiar to potential investors; (ii) design a program to assess and address the environmental and operating problems and risks likely to confront potential investors and Uzemnunaigas in rehabilitating the field; (iii) develop and implement a reorganization and privatization plan to address organizational and management weaknesses within Uzenmunaigas and provide viable corporate vehicles for potential strategic investors; (iv) put in place an effective process for actively and effectively seeking long-term equity and operating partners for the field; and (v) finance the initial investment requirements to rehabilitate the field and prevent further sharp deterioration in its physical condition. The proposed Uzen Oil Field Rehabilitation Project would finance (i) the implementation of a slice of the rehabilitation program for the field as a whole; (ii) consulting and technical services to implement the investment program and expand knowledge of the operating and environmental condition of the field; (iii) start on a program to remediate past environmental damage; and (iv) training of Uzenmunaigas staff and strengthening of management systems. Other aspects of the rehabilitation program, including the systematic promotion of the field to outside investors and the restructuring and privatization of Uzenmunaigas are being implemented under the Petroleum Technical Assistance Project. The proposed Project is viewed by the Government as an important demonstration project in the subsector.
 I. The Energy Sector 9 1.32 Technical Assistance Programs. The Bank was instrumental in assisting the Government in 1993 to prepare a comprehensive program of technical assistance requirements in the energy sector and in mobilizing donor financing for such a program. This assistance was undertaken in conjunction with the Technical Cooperation Program under which the Bank initiated and completed work on a broad range of sector policy issues covering petroleum legislation and taxation, energy pricing and petroleum sector restructuring. The Petroleum Technical Assistance Project (Ln 3744-KZ) was approved by the Board of Executive Directors on June 2, 1994. The PTA Project supports initiatives to strengthen the management of the petroleum subsector and create the conditions necessary for the effective mobilization of foreign investment resources into the subsector. The project provides assistance to the Government and enterprises in the petroleum subsector to: (i) appraise and structure selected investment projects, and seek foreign equity participation in such projects; (ii) review and revamp the petroleum taxation regime; (iii) develop and implement a restructuring, commercialization and privatization program for the sub-sector; and (iv) rationalize and strengthen the domestic capacity for the provision of training in the subsector in both technical and commercial areas. 1.33 Adjustment Operations. The Bank has provided support to the Government in developing a package of price, taxation and institutional reforms in the oil sector (paras 2.11 to 2.38). This package was adopted under the Anti-Crisis Program and was implemented by the Government under the Bank-supported Structural Adjustment operation (Loan 3900-KZ). These reforms resulted in the formal liberalization of crude oil and petroleum products pricing and trade, the dissolution of Munaionimderi (the state-owned monopoly wholesale and retail distributor of petroleum products) and the privatization of its retail distribution activities. Measures have also been instituted to ensure open access to the storage and terminal facilities formerly owned and operated by Munaionimderi. The drafting of a tax code for petroleum and minerals was initiated under this operation and the Bank is providing assistance to the Government in the preparation of the petroleum tax code under the Petroleum Technical Assistance Project. 1.34 As the initial package of support for the petroleum subsector is completed with the proposed Uzen Oil Field Rehabilitation Project, the emphasis of Bank support in the petroleum sector is expected to be on underpinning the subsector's ability to attract private financing for investments. This support would be provided through both the Bank's guarantee instruments and the selective financing of critical investment-related advisory services under the PTA Project. The focus of the Bank's sector assistance strategy and related investment operations are expected to shift increasingly to the power and heat subsectors. The reliability of the power subsector's performance both in provision of power to industry and heat to the population has deteriorated sharply in the past four years. The subsector requires both institutional reforms and investments to ensure its continued viability as a secure supplier of electricity and heat. A dialogue was started in 1992 with the Government and subsector holding group on critical subsectoral issues and the Bank assisted the Government in obtaining grant-financing for the elaboration of key investment issues. Future Bank assistance to the subsector would focus on institutional and regulatory reforms to strengthen the incentives for efficient operations and investments, bolster its cash generating capacity and support private foreign financing. The Bank's investment lending would complement these reforms.

 II. THE OIL SUBSECTOR A. OIL RESERVES AND PRODUCTION 2.1 Kazakstan's crude oil resources (para 1.7) may be characterized as four-tiered: (i) small discovered and appraised but undeveloped or partially developed fields accounting for about 300 million tons of the country's proven and probable oil reserves; (ii) fully developed and producing fields collectively accounting for an estimnated 700 million tons of reserves and virtually all of the country's current oil production; (iii) two giant fields (Tengiz and Karachaganak) that have been partially developed and account for the remainder of the country's proven and probable reserves (1.1 billion tons); and (iv) the huge unexplored potential estimated to be at least as large as currently exploitable reserves. 2.2 The country's known petroleum endowment is significantly under-exploited with production largely confined to a few fields, accounting for a relatively small proportion (33%) of total exploitable reserves. Current (1995) oil production makes Kazakstan the second largest producer among countries of the FSU but accounts for an unusually low proportion of proven reserves (less than 1%) by international norms. 2.3 The low rate of exploitation of reserves reflects the historic lack of adequate technical and financial resources to develop new fields and optimize production from developed fields. Within the FSU, development of the petroleum subsector in Kazakstan faced significant competition for centrally-allocated investment resources from petroleum prospects located elsewhere that were technically less complex to exploit. At the same time, sector pricing and taxation policies and the obligation of enterprises to fund extensive social services led to minimal internal generation of free cash flow for reinvestment in the sector. Since the dissolution of the FSU, the sector's financial capacity has been further eroded by (i) a prolonged period of low and controlled domestic prices in the face of sharp increases towards world market levels in the cost of operating and capital inputs; (ii) limited access to transport infrastructure for exports at higher prices than those obtained within the region; and (iii) until recently, low export prices and large arrears of payments on exports to Russia which, in the absence of transport access to the domestic refineries and other export markets, accounts for over 40% of Kazakstan's oil production. B. PETROLEUM REFINING 2.4 Of the country's three refineries, Atyrau (nominal capacity of 50 million tons), in the north Caspian Sea area, processes exclusively domestic crude and had a crude oil throughput of 4.3 million tons in 1995. Pavlodar (nominal capacity of 7.0 million tons per annum), located in the north-eastern part of the country is wholly dependent on crude oil imports from Russia. The refinery had a crude oil throughput of 3.0 million tons in 1995. The third refinery (nominal capacity of 6.3 million tons), located in Chimkent in the south-eastern part of the country, processes minor amounts of crude oil produced in the region (1.6 million tons in 1994) but is otherwise dependent on imports of crude oil from Russia for the balance of its throughput. It processed a total of 3.7 million tons of crude oil in 1995. The refineries are of varying vintage and condition. The Atyrau refinery, built in 1945, is a fuel and lube oil refinery with obsolete plant and technology. The Chimkent refinery operated as a basic hydro-skimming facility with no installed secondary conversion units until mid- 1995. It consequently had a high yield of low- value residual fuel oil (over 40% of output). Since then, catalytic cracking facilities have been installed, and the yield of higher value light products should increase significantly as the facilities
 11 II. The Oil Subsector are brought fully on-stream. The Pavlodar refinery is one of the most modem refineries in the FSU with its fluidized catalytic cracking facilities. 2.5 Currently, the country's petroleum products production is dominated by a high average yield of heavy fuel oil (40%) with relatively low output of light products (55%). The product structure reflects the general lack of heavy oil conversion capacity and results in large imports of diesel to meet current domestic demand and, at full operating capacity, substantial exports of heavy fuel oil. Restrictions on crude oil imports in recent years have resulted in a precipitous decline in capacity utilization in Pavlodar and Chimkent (from 95% in 1991 to 50% in 1995) and heavy domestic import requirements for gasoline, diesel and heavy fuel oil. 2.6 Bulk physical distribution of petroleum products is mainly by rail with local distribution by road. Except for a pipeline from the Chimkent refinery to Tashkent in neighboring Uzbekistan and product pipelines from Russia serving two industrial towns in the northem part of the country, there are no product pipelines in the country. Given the large annual uni-directional volumes of products that are shipped from the refineries to a few distribution points, it is more efficient technically to use pipelines for bulk physical distribution of products. Whether it is more economic to undertake such investments depends largely on the condition and capacity of the rail system. The economic feasibility of investments in product pipelines is proposed to be studied under the PTA project. 2.7 The Government and the refineries have a number of plans at the moment to: (i) increase the capacity and upgrade the product yield of the Atyrau refinery; (ii) further upgrade the facilities of the Chimkent refinery; (iii) complete the expansion of the capacity of Pavlodar; and (iv) construct a new refinery around Aktau to process the heavy crude with high vanadium and other metallic content that is characteristic of a significant proportion of oil production in the Mangyshlak region. However, the technical, economic and commercial viability of these proposed capacity rehabilitation and expansion plans need to be demonstrated. Prima facie, some of these investment proposals do not appear to be viable given domestic market demand and its regional distribution, export opportunities, transport costs of refined products and the net export value of crude oil. The Government has indicated its intention to use funds provided under the PTA loan to review the economic and commercial feasibility of selected major refinery investment proposals and prepare financing packages for projects demonstrated to be viable. C. FOREIGN INVESTMENT 2.8 The Government has given early and favorable attention to attracting foreign investment in the sector and its promotional efforts have had a large measure of success. To date, more than 32 oil and condensate fields with estimated total proven reserves of 1.5 billion tons of oil equivalent and 1.3 trillion cubic meters of gas (accounting for about 75% of the country's total remaining recoverable petroleum reserves) have been put on offer by the Government and its sector agencies to potential investors for participation in their development and rehabilitation. About 50% of the oil reserves and virtually all of the gas reserves in the fields put on offer so far have been accounted for by the Tengiz field and the Karachaganak field, respectively. For the Tengiz field, a final agreement providing for a 50/50 joint venture was signed between Tengizneftegaz (the Kazakstan production association) and a subsidiary of Chevron in April, 1993. British Petroleum, Agip and Gasprom of Russia negotiated an interim agreement for the development of the Karachaganak field (15% of total estimated reserves offered for participation)
 11. The Oil Subsector 12 in early 1995. Under this agreement, the field's production would be restored to its 1991 levels within a four-year period during which the partners have an option to enter into a production- sharing agreement with the Government for the full-scale development of the field. The remaining oil fields offered for participation are small. Foreign operators, mainly smaller independent oil companies and service contractors, have expressed a good measure of interest in these smaller operations as well. 2.9 Foreign investment agreements in discovered fields entered into or pending approval by the Government now cover about 18 fields with total proven oil reserves of about 1.2 billion tons. 2.10 In addition to the promotion of discovered fields, the Government has also been actively seeking foreign participation in petroleum exploration, particularly in the highly prospective peri- Caspian basin and the Caspian sea-shelf. The Government has also been actively seeking foreign investment and equity participation in the refinery sector. D. SUBSECTOR ISSUES 2.11 While external interest in exploration, development and rehabilitation prospects in the petroleum sector of Kazakstan has been high, there have been considerable delays in concluding agreements with potential investors and gaining Government approval for negotiated contracts. Delays in the flow of external financing once agreements have been concluded have also been substantial. The main factors behind these delays have been: (i) the absence, until recently, of a coherent petroleum legal and contractual framework for petroleum operations; (ii) the lack of a clear taxation regime for petroleum operations, particularly provisions for taxation of potential profits in excess of adequate rates of return to investment in sector operations; (iii) the relative complexity of participation terms and structures offered by potential investors compared to the limited but growing domestic capacity and experience in evaluating and approving investment proposals; and (iv) uncertainties about potential access to transport facilities for export of crude oil and natural gas to international markets. The Government has made considerable progress in addressing these obstacles to the timely flow of foreign investment. However, further actions still remain to be taken by the Government to ensure that the country can continue to attract foreign investment, facilitate the implementation of investmnent agreements and regenerate the performance of the domestic enterprises which will be the mainstay of production in the short to medium term. E. OIL PRICING 2.12 Oil pricing policy in Kazakstan has been strongly influenced by the constraints on the oil sector's access to markets. In the immediate post-independence period, the Government's domestic crude oil pricing policy was to maintain parity with Russian crude oil prices, albeit with a lag, within the framework of inter-republican trade agreements. This explicit linkage of domestic crude oil prices to the Russian domestic price was abandoned as a result of increasing divergences in the value of the Russian and external rouble which culminated in the introduction of a national currency in November 1993. Upon the introduction of the new national currency, the domestic crude oil price was set by the Government at Tenge 100 per ton (US$25 per ton equivalent at the then ruling exchange rate), then equivalent to about 50% of the Russian domestic price and 25% of international export parity levels. The price was maintained at this
 13 11. The Oil Subsector level until March 1994 (para 1.16), by which time it had been eroded to about 5% of international export parity levels and about 15% of the Russian domestic oil price. 2.13 In March 1994, the Government revised the system for price-setting in the oil sector and increased average crude oil prices to Tenge 751 (US$31 equivalent) per ton, equal to Russian import parity prices and about 40% of international export parity levels. However, reflecting the monopsonist powers of the Russian refineries, oil export prices to Russia, while notionally set under inter-republican trade agreements at import prices from Russia, were subject to substantial discounting by Russian refineries. As a result, notwithstanding domestic oil pricing on an import parity basis, the weighted average price of Kazakstan crude oil sales fell substantially short of Russian domestic prices. 2.14 Since mid-1994, the Government and the domestic oil industry have taken a number of actions to bring the effective price for crude oil sales in the domestic and regional market in line with the netback from sales to international markets. 2.15 In the domestic market, the Government has introduced two key measures that are designed to permit the oil producing entities to effectively integrate their operations forward and capture a larger share of the margin between crude oil production costs and light petroleum product retail prices (which, excluding taxes, are broadly comparable to international import parity levels). First, from January 1, 1995, the Government has granted the oil producing companies autonomy to market their crude oil in the domestic and regional market through channels chosen by themselves rather than through the sector holding company under which all of the country's producing and refining enterprises are grouped. Second, the monopoly on wholesale petroleum products procurement and distribution enjoyed by the state distribution holding company has been progressively eroded through the growing advent of toll-processing by third parties, the grant of powers to the refineries to cease shipments for non-payment on sales, the progressive breakup of the holding group's distribution operations and assets and its eventual formal dissolution in April 1995. These measures have made it possible for the oil producers to toll-process crude oil domestically and to market petroleum products in the domestic market through an emerging network of wholesale petroleum products distributors or direct sales. Based on the current ex-refinery petroleum product prices, the product yield of the refineries, transport costs and the toll-processing fees negotiated between the oil producing entities and the refineries, the net value (after VAT but excluding sales expenses) of locally toll-processed crude oil varies from around US$40 per ton (US$5.5 per bbl) at Atyrau to US$77 per ton (US$10.5 per bbl) at Pavlodar. These net values are equivalent to between 43% and 83% of the international export parity price of crude oil before export taxes and between 63% and 120% after export duty imposed on crude oil exports made by domestic oil enterprises. These net values have set a substantially higher benchmark for the pricing of crude oil in domestic trade than the previous anchor to Russian domestic crude oil prices. 2.16 With respect to oil trade with Russia, continuing consolidation in the Russian oil industry in combination with the above changes in oil marketing arrangements in Kazakstan have greatly increased the incentive for trade between oil enterprises on either side of the border on mutually advantageous terms. As the Russian oil industry has become more vertically integrated and geographically consolidated and the Kazakstan oil producers have increasingly been able to enjoy the benefits of vertical integration through toll-processing, the incentives for swap arrangements (Russian delivery of oil to the refineries in eastern Kazakstan in exchange for delivery of oil from
 11. The Oil Subsector 14 Kazakstan at refineries in the Urals and Volga regions of Russia) and closer commercial ties have increased considerably. Formal swap agreements covered about 40% of Kazakstan's 1995 oil production of 17 million tons, although actual perfonnance on the swap agreements was uneven. F. OIL TRANSPORT 2.17 The lack of assured access to export markets outside of the FSU has been one of the major obstacles to significant investment and expansion in oil production. Kazakstan has an extensive network of crude oil pipelines, mostly in the western part of the country (Annex 2. 1). The pipeline network is fully integrated with the pipeline network in the Volga region of Russia through which the country has its only pipeline access to markets outside the FSU. The effective capacity of the pipeline links between the country's oil producing regions and the Russian oil transport system is currently about 16 million tons per annum. Internally, aside from the links between the refinery and oil fields in the western part of the country, the only pipeline link between oil fields and refineries is in the central part of the country. In this region, relatively small oil fields around Kumkol are connected to the trunk pipeline from West Siberia to the South of Kazakstan and Central Asia. 2.18 The total oil transport capacity to all accessible markets is currently estimated at about 26 million tons. The headroom for additional production over the level of production in 1995 is 9 million tons. However, the transport reliability on the available routes is low and the estimated headroom may be subject to sizeable periodic reduction. In particular, export quotas through Russia and the allowable throughout on the pipeline between Atyrau and Samara have been subject to periodic and unpredictable reductions. Without expanded domestic and export pipeline capacity and increased exports to the Caspian Sea region, Kazakstan's crude oil production potential would be capped at about 26 million tons per annum and be subject to a considerable degree of transport-induced volatility. The composition of the country's oil transport capacity and access to markets is detailed in Annex 2.2. 2.19 Government actions to relieve the transport constraint on the country's oil production have centered on two key activities. First, the Government has been supporting the efforts of a consortium comprising Russia, Oman and Kazakstan in promoting the development of a pipeline from Kazakstan through Stavropol in Russia to the Black Sea port of Novorissysk. The proposed pipeline has a planned ultimate capacity of 35 million tons per annum, sufficient to accommodate the projected export throughput from all discovered but undeveloped or partially developed oil fields in the country up to 2010. The estimated external financing requirement of the proposed pipeline is around US$1.3 billion. The consortium was formed in 1992. It initially encountered significant problems in attracting equity and debt financing from potential users (oil companies with significant proposed investments in Kazakstan) and financial institutions. Two main reasons accounted for this lack of success in raising financing: (i) a strong perception that the shareholding structure was inequitable to new investors; while (ii) the proposed tariffs for use of the system unduly leveraged the potential return to the shareholders at the expense of the profits of the users. In the light of the market reception to its search for financing, the consortium, in 1995, restructured the project into two phases with the first phase concentrating on developing terminal facilities close to Novorissysk and de-bottlenecking segments of the oil pipeline network in Russia to allow incremental oil exports of 11 million tons. About 4.0 million tons of this amount was earmarked for Kazakstan. This restructuring reduced the initial financing requirements but did not increase the interest of investors in the project. In March 1996, the
 15 II. The Oil Subsector capital and organizational structure of the proposed venture was also restructured. This restructuring was formally ratified by the participating states in April 1996. By addressing the fundamental reason for the lack of outside interest in participating in the pipeline project, this latest restructuring has improved substantially the prospects for raising financing for the project. 2.20 Despite the uncertainties and delays in developing an export pipeline, foreign oil companies have continued to be keenly interested in acquiring rights (licenses) to explore for and to develop oil reserves in Kazakstan but without assuming any obligation to invest substantial amounts to produce the reserves. These rights (or options) to develop reserves can be valuable as long as there are reasonable prospects for the ultimate development of an export pipeline and the profitable development of such reserves in the future. Given the recent positive developments on the export pipeline, the risk that companies will not exercise their options to undertake investment to fully develop fields now appears to be low. There are however other remaining areas of uncertainty to be resolved, including the concerns of the Government of Turkey about the safety and environmental implications of increasing oil tanker transport through the Bosphorus and Dardanelles. 2.21 Second, the Government has been considering the development of a crude oil pipeline to link the oil fields in the west of the country and the refineries in the east of the country. The development of this link would entail construction of a pipeline between the western oil fields and Kumkol and expansion of the capacity of the pipeline between Kumkol and the trunk pipeline from Russia to Central Asia. The estimated cost of this proposed investment is about US$900 million. A technical feasibility study of the project has already been undertaken. The economic costs associated with the proposed pipeline at likely throughput levels are substantially higher than those incurred under the existing oil procurement and transport arrangements. For the proposed investment to be economically viable, these higher economic costs of transport would have to be offset by: (i) a high probability and frequency of disruptions of the existing oil import arrangements and with substantial economic costs associated with these supply disruptions; and (ii) a high probability that future oil supplies from Russia would be significantly lower than the requirements of the refineries; and that such shortfalls can be met at lower economic costs by diversion and transport of oil from the country's western oil fields rather than through the import of petroleum products. A comprehensive economic evaluation of the proposed investment, based on a full assessment and simulation of the risks of disruption and shortfalls in the supply of crude oil faced without the project, is currently being undertaken by the Government with financing under the Petroleum Technical Assistance Project. G. ORGANIZATION OF THE SUBSECTOR 2.22 The petroleum subsector is organized by functional specialization under the administrative oversight of the MOG and MG. Oil and gas production, transmission and distribution fall under the MOG, while petroleum exploration is under the MG. The oil and gas production and related activities are further organized by commodity specialization into two main groups. Oil production, refining and transportation are managed mostly by functionally-based regional Associations. Up to early 1995, these Associations were closely controlled by Munaigas, the holding company for this segment of the petroleum industry. Seven regional oil production associations, each consisting of oil producing and related operating and service organizations, account for all of the country's current oil production. Similarly, all crude oil transport within the country is undertaken by four regionally-based pipeline associations.
 11. The Oil Subsector 16 2.23 Gas production and transmission are grouped under a holding entity, Kazakhgas. At present, Kazakhgas' portfolio is dominated by the Karachaganak field and the transit gas transmission line from Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan to Russia. 2.24 In the MG, petroleum exploration activities are managed by regionally-based exploration drilling and geophysical entities grouped into associations along functional lines. The activities of these entities are financed through budgetary appropriations from the geologic fund which is derived from taxes on the revenues of oil producing entities. 2.25 In addition to these three main commodity and functional groupings, regionally-organized petroleum product bulk transport, storage and retail distribution activities were managed, until April 1995, within the public sector under the holding company Munaionimderi. Natural gas distribution operations are managed by regionally-based distribution companies. 2.26 In 1993, the Government adopted a three-phased strategy for organizational reform in the subsector based on its generic strategy for enterprise reform in the economy. First, the existing subsector enterprises were to be corporatized under the supervision of the holding groups. Second, the corporatized entities were to be restructured to promote competition and, where relevant, a framework for the regulation of natural monopolies developed. Third, selected enterprises were to be privatized. 2.27 The results of organizational reform in the subsector have been mixed. Most of the commercial enterprises in the subsector have been incorporated as joint-stock companies. However, virtually all the companies have been incorporated as closed joint-stock companies (90% equity ownership by the state and 10% by the management and workforce) with few changes in enterprise objectives and management. On restructuring, the Government has been faced with three broad options: (i) the break-up of the subsector into competing independent corporate units, both upstream and downstream; (ii) the preservation of the vertically-integrated inherited industry structure but with restructured internal organizational arrangements to promote efficient performance coupled with divestiture of selected operating activities; or (iii) the break-up of the inherited industry structure into a small number of competing vertically-integrated entities with common pipeline and other facilities spun-off into separate regulated common-carrier or service entities. However, a consensus in the Government on a preferred option for restructuring has been slow to emerge reflecting deep divisions on the appropriate balance between fragmentation of the subsector to promote competition and the promotion of a single or a cluster of large integrated national oil companies, private or publicly-owned. 2.28 Notwithstanding the absence of a consensus on the ultimate structure of the subsector, the Government has made steady progress in dealing with some of the demonstrably unsatisfactory aspects of the subsector's performance arising from its inherited structure: (i) the degree of control exercised by Munaigas over oil producing enterprises has been reduced considerably to allow these enterprises greater autonomy in making commercial decisions; (ii) Munaionimderi has been dissolved and a significant proportion of the petroleum products retail distribution businesses have been privatized; the bulk storage and related transport assets of Munaionimderi -- the main source of monopoly power in this industry segment -- are undergoing privatization and a regulatory system is currently being developed to foster adequate access to such facilities by distributors; (iii) a start has been made in rationalizing the internal organizational arrangements in the Production Associations to promote efficient management; this process has resulted so far
 17 II. The Oil Subsector in the separation of one major oil producing enterprise (Uzenneft) from its parent PA; (iv) the wholesale market for gas has been liberalized with non-discriminatory access by third parties to the transmission network operated by Kazakgas. 2.29 On privatization, the underlying private sector participation in the upstream oil industry is significant and is likely to grow substantially in the future: (i) existing joint-venture agreements cover about 40% of discovered reserves; (ii) the Government has started to selectively divest of parts of its equity interest in joint-venture organizations to foreign oil companies; and (iii) foreign oil company participation in exploration is substantial. However, much of this private sector involvement reflects direct interest in reserves separated from enterprises rather than in existing enterprises. Progress on the privatization of existing enterprises has been limited to date to the sale of petroleum product and liquified petroleum gas distribution activities and companies, conducted under the Government's small scale and mass privatization program. Larger operating units and entities were planned to be selectively privatized on a case-by-case basis, principally through attracting strategic foreign equity investors. This process started slowly but is now proceeding at a fast pace. In early 1994, the Government contracted the services of several investment advisors to prepare proposals for the sale by international tender of equity interests in two small oil-producing PAs with extensive undeveloped reserves and in the Chimkent refinery. The investment solicitation documents for these activities were completed recently and the Government has started approaching potential strategic investors. 2.30 To date, relatively little attention has been devoted to addressing: (a) the privatization or disposition of enterprises and assets in which foreign investment interest is likely to be limited; and (b) the participation of the Kazakstan public in the privatization of the sector outside of small scale distribution activities. However, the Government's objective now is to broaden domestic private sector participation in the sector through: (i) further divestment of its stake in enterprises with strategic foreign partners; (ii) the restructuring and privatization of the operations and assets of enterprises in which there is no immediate foreign investor interest; and (iii) the privatization of the residual operating activities and assets of enterprises with foreign strategic partners in selected activities. This enhanced approach will be adopted in the proposed project. Specifically, the Government has incorporated Uzenmunaigas as an open joint-stock company and plans to privatize it through (a) the divestment of part of the state's equity holding to the public; (b) the attraction of outside firms as strategic investors in specific operating units; and (c) the separation, incorporation and privatization of some operating units. H. THE LEGAL FRAMEWORK FOR OIL OPERATIONS 2.31 A Petroleum Law (PL) was approved by the legislature on first reading in November, 1994 and passed by Presidential Decree on June 28, 1995. The passage of the PL completes the basic package of legislative measures governing investments and operations in the oil sector. The other complementary legislation include: (i) the Law on the Subsoil which vests ownership of all subsoil resources in the state, provides for the distribution of licensing powers for exploitation of the subsoil between the central and local governments, designates the institutions responsible for managing significant aspects of the licensing process, and lays the basis for the levy of fees for the use of natural resources; (ii) the Decree of the Cabinet of Ministers on Procedures for Licensing of the Subsoil (August 8, 1994); (iii) the Foreign Investment Law (December 1994) which specifies the basis on which government financial guarantees are to be provided and provides for (a) the stabilization of the legal regime in existence at the inception of an
 11. The Oil Subsector 18 investment; (b) guarantees against expropriation in line with international standards; (c) guarantees of investors' ability to repatriate hard currency earnings; and (d) dispute resolution procedures under investment contracts; and (iv) the Decree on Taxes and Obligatory Payments to fhe Budget (General Tax Code) (April 25, 1995) which defines, inter-alia, the framework for the taxation of petroleum operations. Kazakstan is the first state of the FSU to have completed the basic package of petroleum legislation. 2.32 The PL provides for petroleum operations to be conducted through production sharing agreements, concession contracts or risk service contracts and addresses adequately the substantive issues likely to affect the efficient development of the petroleum sector. The provisions of the PL take precedence over any conflicting provision on petroleum matters in other existing legislation and provide for the grand-fathering of all provisions within contracts entered into prior to its passage. Some important issues remain unresolved under the PL but their proposed treatment under other existing or pending arrangements are satisfactory. In particular, the agency to be vested with powers to implement the Government's policy in the subsector is not specified in the PL, reflecting the absence of consensus during the development of the law on an agency to perform this role on a permanent basis. However, the powers of such a body are clearly defined and the institutional arrangements presently in place for the administration of the law are satisfactory. The PL provides the framework for the taxation of petroleum operations, including adequate guarantees on the stability of fiscal arrangements over the duration of negotiated contracts. Finally, the PL does not specify the regulations to govern petroleum operations but grants authority to the Government to develop appropriate regulations. This arrangement gives flexibility to the Government to introduce rules for petroleum operations as necessary. However, such rules might require legislative approval to come into force and this could seriously compromise the Government's responsiveness to changing industry circumstances. The Government is currently in the process of developing model contracts to guide the negotiation of agreements under the PL. A work program for the development of regulations is also under implementation. The Government, using resources available under the PTA project and form bilateral agencies, has started to address the problem of strengthening its capacity to administer both the contracts already in force and future licenses and agreements. I. THE TAXATION FRAMEWORK FOR OIL OPERATIONS 2.33 Recently issued Presidential Decrees on a PL and "On Taxes and Other Obligatory Payments to the Budget" have introduced a coherent framework for the taxation of petroleum operations. First, all petroleum operations are to be subject to the provisions of the general income tax regime covering the treatment of profits, interest payments and distribution of profits, losses, revenues and expenses (including depreciation). Second, petroleum operations are to be subject to specified special taxes and payments -- bonuses, royalties, and additional profits taxes - -- to be imposed at rates to be negotiated in individual contracts. Third, petroleum operations may be subject to other taxes to be negotiated and defined in individual contracts. 2.34 The general income tax code provides for: (i) profits tax at a rate of 30%; (ii) depreciation of physical assets and exploration and intangible costs at rates specified in the General Tax Code; (iii) loss carry-forward for five years; (iv) VAT at a gross rate of 20% on domestic sales and imported material; and (v) withholding taxes on interest and dividends of 15%. VAT on inputs in excess of VAT on sales for any monthly reporting period is reimbursable by the Tax Inspectorate, eliminating the additional tax burden that can arise where domestic sales are a
 19 11. The Oil Subsector relatively small proportion of total sales, as is likely to be the case for foreign oil investors in Kazakstan. The depreciation schedules in the General Tax Code are in general longer than those available in other capital-seeking oil producing regions and thus provide less competitive tax shields and investment incentives. The bases for assessment of additional profits taxes and royalties have yet to be defined. Hitherto, the bases for assessment of additional profits taxes have varied widely from contract to contract contributing to the complexity of negotiations of individual contracts and subsequent tax administration. 2.35 The Government's strategy for tax reform includes the development of specific subsidiary chapters of the General Tax Code to cover detailed provisions for the taxation of petroleum and mineral mining operations. The subsidiary chapter on petroleum operations is expected to cover the detailed accounting rules for the computation of taxable income, and the basic features of an additional profits tax and royalty regime and the methodology to be used in defining excess profits subject to additional income tax. Preliminary work undertaken by the Ministry of Finance indicates that: (i) a preferred additional profits tax regime is the "discounted cashflow trigger" tax under which cashflow generated over and above a threshold rate of return would be subject to an additional income tax; and (ii) a royalty regime is likely to be structured on a sliding scale with progressively higher marginal rates of royalty on increasing production levels but with the overall average rate of royalty restricted to a modest level. However, specific choices are expected to be made only after a thorough assessment of available options. 2.36 The proposed petroleum tax reforms are broadly consistent with the principles embodied in negotiated fiscal arrangements for joint ventures. In contrast, domestic oil operations have hitherto been subject to: (i) a tax on revenues (8%) to finance the exploration activities of MG- related entities; joint-ventures with foreign participation have generally been exempted from this tax; and (ii) fixed rental payment. There is no longer an institutional link between the MG enterprises and the PAs and thus no longer a rationale for the geological fund. Also, its economic rationale is weak: since the levy pays no regard to the underlying profitability of field operations, it can adversely affect the financial performance of otherwise economically viable fields. This effect would be resolved by a royalty regime better tailored to production levels and cost structures of domestically-managed oil fields. Rental payments were introduced in December 1991 to reduce enterprise net profit margins to no more than two-times the industry average and were earmarked for the financing of urban transport services. Although eligibility to pay was determined by profitability, the tax was imposed as a fixed sum per ton of sales. The rationale and administration of the tax was subsequently undermined by inflation in input prices and its impact on both the appropriate yardstick for determining adequate profitability and the solvency of enterprises to pay assessed rentals. By mid-1993, rental payment levels had been modified four times and had become applicable to only two PAs. At present, the payment is applied as a negotiated royalty on revenues. 2.37 In addition to the geological levy and rental payments, domestic enterprises are subject to export duties on oil exports. Foreign oil operations are exempt from this duty. At the prevailing rate of ECU 23 per ton, the duty can serve as a relatively severe disincentive to domestic oil enterprises. In practice, due to external restrictions on exports, prior allocation of available export capacity mostly to foreign joint-ventures and liberalized domestic oil prices, the distortionary effects of the duty are limited. In principle, however, the discriminatory application of the duty could distort investment decisions by making certain forms of investment potentially unattractive to domestic enterprises.
