 III. THE LESSONS OF EXPERIENCE 3.1 Since 1980, the Bank has approved about 106 loans and credits in the petroleum subsector for a total of about US$7 billion to about 56 countries. The loans cover most petroleum subsectors but with the largest number of loans in petroleum exploration promotion activities. About 90 project completion reports (PCR) have been prepared covering both technical assistance and investment operations. The PCRs indicate that most projects achieved their objectives, both institutional and production. In particular, most Bank projects in the subsector were relatively successful in training local staff and transferring modem petroleum operating practices. However, a recurring theme in most projects is a significant lag in implementation schedules. Most of these slippages reflect the borrowers' initial unfamiliarity with Bank procurement procedures, fragmentation of responsibilities among subsector agencies and cumbersome internal clearance procedures between subsector agencies and entities. 3.2 OED studies of the Bank's lending experience in the subsector suggest that investment projects have been relatively unsuccessful vehicles for promoting subsector policy reforms. Rather, most of the Bank's success in policy reform has risen from policy-based lending operations, for example, in Bangladesh, Egypt and Pakistan. Similarly, progress in changing subsector organizational arrangements and management practices through Bank investment operations have tended to be limited owing to the Bank's generally ambitious reform programs and strong vested interests against significant organizational changes. 3.3 Arising from its initial lending experience in petroleum promotion and investment operations, the Bank has developed a set of guidelines governing lending operations in the subsector. The guidelines cover both subsector and project specific conditions designed to ensure effective perfomnance of subsector operations and the creation of a climate conducive to attracting and generating investment resources for the subsector. The general subsector conditions cover: (i) prices: prices should be set to ensure efficient use of energy and to provide incentives for exploration, development and production of petroleum resources; (ii) taxation: the level of taxation should be set both to grant the government a reasonable share of any possible rent from petroleum operations and to ensure an adequate level of profitability for the enterprises; (iii) legalframework: a clear and transparent legal and contractual framework to assure enterprises and potential private investors of a stable basis for their operations should be in place; and (iv) role of government and enterprises: enterprises should be given autonomy to undertake their operations on a commercial basis subject to accountability for their performance while governments should focus on developing subsector policy and overseeing the efficient operation of the subsector through its policy and regulatory instruments. 3.4 Project-specific conditions cover the need for sound internal management procedures to ensure adequate returns to investments through efficient procurement procedures, effective financial accounting and management practices, adequate capital budgeting procedures and sound operating practices.
 22 III. The Lessons of Experience 3.5 The preparation and design of the project take full account of these lessons of the Bank's lending experience in the subsector. Specifically, significant reforms in the petroleum subsector pricing, taxation and organizational structure have been agreed upon or implemented already under the Bank's first Structural Adjustment Operations (FY95). Also, implied strategies for effective project design reflected in the Bank's experience have been fully incorporated in the proposed project. 3.6 The proposed project is the first Bank investment operation in Kazakstan's energy sector. However, recent experience in processing and implementing the Petroleum Technical Assistance project and in processing the ultimately abortive (at the Government's request) Uzen Oil Field component of the Rehabilitation Loan (FY94) has confirmed substantial weaknesses in procurement and project management capacity in general in the proposed project entity. More specifically, there is very limited familiarity with Bank procedures and a substantial risk of project implementation delays. The project implementation arrangements proposed under the project have been designed to overcome these weaknesses. Other important lessons learnt from the processing and implementation of these projects include the following: (a) the importance of early identification of all agencies and enterprises that are critical to the success of a project and the need to pay particular attention to promoting early ownership and a co-ordinated approach to the project amongst such stakeholders; and (b) the importance of promoting the substantial involvement of local experts in the management and execution of a project.
 IV. THE BENEFICIARY: UZENMUNAIGAS A. BACKGROUND 4.1 The Uzen oil field is situated in the southern Mangyshlak region, around the Caspian sea. The field was discovered in 1959. Field development commenced in 1961 and production in 1965. The original total oil in place is estimated at 1.1 billion tons, making the field the second largest oil field yet discovered in Kazakstan (after Tengiz). The field is characterized by an elongated structure stretching some 38 km and large variations in the permeability of reservoir rocks. Uzen oil is sweet (0.17% sulphur), medium light (340 API) with high tar and paraffin content and a high pour-point, with the oil congealing at a relatively high temperature (32 Centigrade). The proportion of the total oil in place ultimately recoverable has been estimated by consultants engaged by the Bank at between 30% and 35%, depending on the level of investment and the degree of success in coping with: (a) the complex operational problems associated with the field's reservoirs and the properties of its oil; and (b) the consequences of the operating practices instituted over the field's producing history. A more detailed description of the field's geology is provided in Annex 4.1. 4.2 For most of its operating life to date, Uzen has been the largest producing field in the country. Notwithstanding steep annual declines since 1989, Uzen production in 1995 accounted for about 15% of the country's total crude oil production. Cumulative production since the field was brought into production amounts to about 245 million tons (1.8 billion barrels) or about 22.3% of the original oil in place. The economically recoverable remaining reserves are estimated at more than 100 million tons1 (750 million barrels based on the specific gravity of Uzen oil), making the Uzen field the largest fully-operational oil field in the country. However, there is a substantial risk that the technical and commercial management and investments necessary to realize this additional oil recovery may not be forthcoming. Under such conditions, production in Uzen is likely to cease within the next five years with the additional recovery of oil limited to about 10 million tons. 4.3 Uzen is a microcosm of the domestic oil industry. It typifies the range of operational, commercial and institutional problems that, inadequately addressed in the past, have resulted in the loss of production from substantial oil reserves which can be made-up only at significantly higher costs in the future and with substantial delays in the flow of benefits to the economy. B. ORGANIZATION AND MANAGEMENT 4.4 The Uzen oil field is operated by Uzenmunaigas. Uzenmunaigas, a PA, was formed in November 1994 to assume sole management control over all activities and assets related to the operation of the Uzen field. Management control of Uzen oil field operations had hitherto been divided between Uzenneft -- the field operating unit -- and Mangistaumunaigas -- the regional PA. I. The level of economically recoverable remaining reserves depends on a number of variables such as oil prices, operating costs and technical efficiency in the recovery of oil reserves. Given changes in these variables, economically recoverable remaining reserves in the Uzen oil field could conceivably be as high as 200 million tons -- the amount of technically recoverable remaining reserves estimated by the relevant Kazakstan competent bodies.
 24 IV. The Beneficiary: Uzenmunaigas 4.5 Uzenneft was created in 1964 as a field operating unit under the direct administrative control of the Ministry of Oil of the FSU. It was transformed into a legally autonomous enterprise in 1989 by decree under the USSR Law on State Enterprises. Under its charter, Uzenneft was granted operational autonomy in its management of the field but subject to production targets and guidelines set by its regional PA. Apart from its operating objectives, the charter of Uzenneft requires it to promote social development in its area of operation. This area has grown from a small nomadic settlement into a relatively large town of 70,000 inhabitants who are economically dependent on the oil field and its related operations. 4.6 Mangistaumunaigas (MMG) was established in 1975 as the supervisory body of the oil producing enterprises and supporting service organizations (drilling, transport, research, etc.) operating in the Mangyshlak region. It was transformed into a legally autonomous enterprise in November 1992. Under its 1992 charter, MMG was empowered to establish pooled funds (drawn from the operating entities) for investments, insurance, procurement of equipment and supplies and housing and social infrastructure, with the allocation of investments to be determined according to regional development priorities. This provision led to a significant erosion in the commercial autonomy of Uzenneft and its ability to make effective operating decisions as control over procurement management, investments, oil marketing and sales revenues was progressively assumed by MMG and much of the cash flow generated from Uzenneft operations was reinvested elsewhere without clear commercial justification. 4.7 Uzenmunaigas was created by the Government to address the organizational weaknesses arising from its relationship with MMG, namely the fragmentation of control over operating and commercial decisions and the subordination of its commercial interest to other regional social and economic development objectives. Uzenmunaigas was formed by the merger of Uzenneft (including the autonomous support groups under its direct supervision) with all MMG divisions or units that were wholly or largely dependent on Uzenneft for their workload or that were based in the Uzen area. The merger consolidated all aspects of the operating and commercial management of the Uzen field within one organizational unit with (a) three (3) major entities (divisions) with outside markets for their outputs; and (b) ten (10) autonomous service units. The three major divisions are: (i) oil producing activities based on the Uzenneft operations; (ii) Kazak Gas Processing Plant (KGP), an Uzen-based LPG and ethane extraction plant using gas feedstock from Uzen and Zhetybai oil fields; and (iii) Mangistau Gas Producers, a non-associated gas producing company. The service units were former "structural units" of MMG which provided oil field services--drilling, transport, infrastructure maintenance, well plugging, etc.--to its oil and gas producing entities on a contract basis. An organizational chart of Uzenmunaigas is attached as Chart 1. 4.8 For management purposes, Uzenmunaigas was structured into 26 self-accounting units, managed as profit centers, and comprising the divisions, service units and seven former autonomous structural units of Uzenneft and six internal units of one of the service units. A schematic representation of the structure of Uzenmunaigas is shown in Chart 2. 4.9 The November 1994 re-organization left a number of weaknesses which the Government recognized would need to be addressed in order to create an appropriate framework to foster commercial management of the Uzen field:
 IV. The Beneficiary: Uzenmunaigas 25 First, the operating mandate of Uzenmnunaigas needs to be strengthened. Uzenrunaigas continued to be governed by a charter that gave it neither clear commercial goals nor the powers to operate commercially. It operated under the effective supervisory and administrative control of MOG which exercised considerable influence over its investment and operating activities. It had no well-defined framework governing the appropriate use of its revenues and profits to ensure its financial and operating viability. Second, Uzeninunaigas' organization needs to be revamped. The rapid assimilation of many structural units into the Uzenneft structure had exacerbated an already inefficient internal management structure. Uzenneft was fragmented into a large number of autonomous functionally-based activity centers that were coordinated only at the level of the General Director. This structure was further complicated by the reorganization under which (a) the number of activity centers has increased significantly; (b) entities that were operating as autonomous businesses have been hastily absorbed as activity centers under functional managers; these entities have become sources of additional operating costs for the organization without, in most cases, any demonstrable commercial benefits to Uzenmunaigas; and (c) the span of control of the General Director and his coordinating responsibilities have been expanded substantially without any improvements in the enterprises's management control systems. Third, the excess staffing within the organization needs to be addressed. The reorganization of MMG shifted a substantial direct financial responsibility for supporting a large additional labor force from MMG and its other oil producing units to Uzenneft. Prior to the reorganization, Uzenneft with a total of 3000 staff (including the work force of its structural units and social services agencies supported by it) was over-staffed and had attempted, unsuccessfully (due to the resistance of the municipal authorities), to relinquish direct responsibility for the staffing and financing of social services in the city. The consolidation of the structural units of MMG with Uzenneft has compounded the problem of excess staff through the transfer of many non-viable operating units to Uzenneft. The merger led to a doubling in the number of staff mainly dedicated to oil production and supporting operations to around 7,000 and an increase in the total staff within the organization as a whole to about 13,000. This staffing level is extremely high in relation to current and feasible future Uzen oil production and the business activity of the other operations. Finally, the management and skills base of the enterprise needs strengthening. The creation of Uzenmunaigas led to further and significant erosion in management skills available to the Uzen operations, which had already suffered from significant out-migration of traditional oil field workers to other regions of the FSU. The enterprise lost both key senior technical management staff attracted by better career prospects in the bigger and more diversified MMG and ready access to key management services and functions formerly centralized in MMG. These management services include reservoir and production planning and management, engineering and computing services, financial management, procurement management and marketing. Post-reorganization, Uzenmunaigas is faced with both recruiting experienced replacement staff and developing essential management systems and capabilities for its core oil producing operations.

C. FIELD FACILIrES AND INRASTRUCTURE 4.13 A detailed description of the production facilities and infrastructure of the Uzen field is given at Annex 4.3. The field has a total of about 3,290 production wells of which about 1,600 are currently (June 1995) inoperative. About 164 of the wells employ gas lift for production with the balance operated on sucker rod pumps. The average spacing of wells is 14.5 hectares per well. Water injection was instituted in 1967 to maintain reservoir pressure. Of the field's total of 1,249 injection wells, about 944 are currently (June 1995) active. About 120,000 tons of sea water is injected daily into the reservoir. 4.14 The oil processing infrastructure of the field comprises 70 group gathering stations served by about 250 sputniks and a central processing plant located about 40 km from the field. The backbone of the oil processing system is a network of approximately 2,900 km of fluid gathering lines. The water injection system, including a sea water supply line of 150 km from the Caspian seaport of Aktau, comprises 1,516 km of pipelines, four water pumping stations and 26 injection stations. The present surface production facilities, including the sea water injection system, were designed by the All Union Oil Scientific Research Institute in Moscow. However, the design as well as the construction of the facilities were carried out without apparent adequate consideration for corrosion protection, quality assurance and environmental protection. Coupled with insufficient recurrent investments for maintenance and inadequate maintenance practices, the facilities are extensively and heavily corroded and subject to frequent failures. Consultants engaged by the Bank to review the condition of the field's oil processing infrastructure have concluded that the facilities are close to the end of their useful lives and will require major rehabilitation in the short to medium term. E. ENVIRONMENTAL CONDMONS 4.20 Environmental conditions in the Uzen Field are typical of those in the majority of oil production operations in the FSU. They reflect a legacy of general neglect of environmental issues and the inadequacy of environmental management and compliance during the Soviet period. There were few incentives for effective environmental management but substantial pressures on oil producers to produce as much oil as possible and as early as possible. The pressures to produce large amounts of oil were reinforced by substantial incentives for achieving or surpassing various production quotas for fluid and oil production, volumes of exploratory and development drilling, water-flooding volumes, etc. At the same time, while there existed an extensive framework of environmental legislation and regulatory standards, compliance and enforcement mechanisms were weak. As a result of this framework of incentives, oil field operations were characterized, by among other things, dense well-spacing, excessive and often irrational use of water-flooding and lack of environmental safeguards in equipment and operations. 4.21 The Environmental Assessment conducted by the Government (with financial assistance of the Government of Canada through a Bank-administered trust fund) as part of the preparation of the project has identified the following existing environmental conditions in the Uzen oil field and neighboring areas: Air. The Uzen area air basin is subject to significant air pollution through emissions of various pollutants arising from oil spills and leaks, gas flaring, and chronic excessive emissions from industrial equipment and plants, particularly from KGP's facilities. Uzenmunaigas and the local environment agencies do not perform systematic and regular monitoring of emission levels in the area. Concentrations of nitrogen dioxide, sulphur dioxide and volatile organic compounds are many times the maximum permissible levels. For instance, sulphur dioxide concentrations in the Uzen field have been observed to be up to 20 times higher, and those in the town of Zhana Uzen up to 10 times higher, than the maximum permissible concentrations.
 30 IV. The Beneficiary: Uzemnrunaigas Surface Water. There are no pernanent surface water bodies in the field area. However, the limited runoff during periodic storms transports pollutants to local topographic depressions, contributing to creation of localities with relatively high surface concentrations of pollutants. Ground Water. The ground water aquifer in the field area is relatively deep (more than 70 meters) and the local soils are of low perrneability. The environmental impact of field operations on the groundwater aquifer has been limited to occasional pollution by produced fluid and injected sea water arising from the poor integrity of cementing and casing corrosion in water injection wells. However, since the groundwater in the field and its immediate vicinity is characterized by high natural salinity and is not used for either industrial or household purposes, this pollution is not considered to be threatening to water supplies. The only source of potable water in the area is in sand dune aquifers located about 30 km from the oil field. These aquifers provide about 30 % of the potable water supply to the Uzen area and are not affected directly by operations in the Uzen field. However, the potable water requirements of the field and poor water use practices have contributed to the rapid harvesting of the aquifers and, given the aquifers' low recharge rate, possible endangerment of this source of supply. Landform and Soils. Substantial physical land disturbances are evident around the field, particularly in the areas of dense well spacing. Most of these disturbances are the result of vehicle traffic and soil mounding. There are few well-defined access roads in the field, traffic discipline is poor and there is little restoration of sites after earth-moving works. Across the field, there are numerous pits and depressions filled with tar and formation-water. Some of these receptacles are planned storage or disposal sites but many are also the result of accidental leaks and spills. The largest of these pits occupies an area of more than 70 hectare and contains an estimated 300,000 tons of a mixture of produced water and heavy hydrocarbon fractions---one of the largest oil lakes in the FSU. Vegetation and Wildlife. Most of the native vegetation has been destroyed in the field within approximately 50 meters of wellheads, around infrastructure facilities (group stations, central processing facilities, etc.), in areas of intensive vehicular traffic, and in and around various pits, waste dumps, and dikes. The wildlife in the area is limited. However, field operations have prompted the extensive migration of wildlife from the area. Land Use and Social Impacts. The area occupied by field operations can sustain only a limited ainount of grazing in its virgin state. The withdrawal of lands from traditional camel grazing has thus had only a relatively moderate negative impact. However, the social structure of the indigenous local communities changed significantly as a substantial migrant population moved to the area and local inhabitants abandoned traditional occupations to seek employment in the field and related industries and services. These changes affected settlement patterns as well, displacing traditional small semi-nomadic communities by an industrial town that is dependent on continuing petroleum production for its existence.

The administration of environmental and occupational safety regulations within the Uzen oil field and Uzenmunaigas' industrial facilities is performed by the local branch of the Sanitation and Epidemiological Service. The monitoring of the impact of oil production and related operations on environmental conditions in the area, outside the industrial sites, is the responsibility of the Environmental Protection Committee. In addition, other separate autonomous agencies exist for the protection of marine life, wildlife and game, forests (including forestry management), and soils.  V. THE REHABILITA TION PROGRAM A. REHABILITATION STRATEGY 5.1 A detailed assessment of Uzen Oil Field's reservoirs and facilities was undertaken by consultants (financed under a Bank-administered Government of Canada Trust Fund) in 1993. The consultants concluded that the total recovery of oil from the field could range from 30% to 35% of the original oil-in-place in the field (of which about 23% has already been recovered), if a rehabilitation program is instituted to address four key problems faced by the field: (i) the inefficiency of the water flooding; (ii) the accumulation of wax in wells; (iii) the inefficiency of downhole pumps; and (iv) the inadequate well completion practices. The consultants identified a potential to increase average oil production, per well by about 140%, from about 42 bbl/day to 105 bbl/day. In addition, at peak production after the rehabilitation of all producing wells, the annual rate of extraction of oil would increase from a current 1.2% of the estimated remaining oil-in-place to between 2.5% and 3.0%. With sustained improvements in field operations, the subsequent decline in production would moderate to the pre-1989 rate of around 5% per annum compared to the post-1989 average rate of decline of over 20% per annum. The surface infrastructure assessment confirmed that the present facilities are close to the end of their useful lives and, except for a few salvageable pumps and facilities, would require complete replacement in the near future. 5.2 Based on these assessments, Uzenmunaigas has formulated a preliminary strategy for the rehabilitation of the field as follows: a. The rehabilitation (major workover) of all currently active producer wells that meet economic viability criteria; b. The rehabilitation of injector wells serving the rehabilitated producer wells; C. The replacement of all flow lines, first-stage separators and gathering stations and oil and fluid transfer lines; d. Subject to the economic and financial constraints faced, the rehabilitation on a modular basis of the central processing facility and installation of an intermediate fluid reduction facility or the phased replacement of remote central processing by construction of in-field processing facilities; e. The rehabilitation of the water injection stations; f. The maximization of the use of recycled produced water and the extensive chemical and mechanical treatment of recycled and make-up sea water; g. The replacement and shortening of the current water supply system by the relocation of the water intake source from Aktau to Kazak Bay and the construction of a 70 km water pipeline from Kazak Bay to the field; and h. The modification of the waterflooding pattern by selective drilling and shut-in of injection and producer wells.
 36 V. The Rehabilitation Program 5.3 The proposed rehabilitation strategy would have important environmental benefits. The extensive replacement of the surface production facilities and changes in operating practices designed to prevent premature corrosion of the facilities and reduce operating costs would prevent future contamination of the field from oil spills, the minimization of the need to dispose of produced fluid and a significant reduction in the requirement of make-up water from the Caspian Sea for water-flooding operations. In addition, Uzenmunaigas would utilize part of the free cash flow from any rehabilitation program to finance the remediation of past environmental damage to the field. B. CONSTRANTS ON THE IMPLEMENTATION OF A RE4ABiLBTATION PROGRAM 5.10 There are substantial impediments to the implementation of a full rehabilitation program. The program would require total financing of US$0.9 billion and, assuming that all available cashflow from the program is reinvested in the field, projected external financing of about US$0.2 to $0.3 billion. Uzenmunaigas cannot self-finance the investment requirements for the program or raise the program's financing requirements domestically. In addition, the enterprise does not have the technical or project management experience to execute effectively a rehabilitation program of such scale and complexity in a way that will minimize external fmancing requirements. The ability of Uzenmunaigas to implement the program depends critically on its capacity to attract both foreign financial and technical resources. However, Uzenmunaigas has faced three sets of constraints on its ability to attract such resources: (i) the relative attractiveness of Kazakstan country conditions for foreign oil investors; (ii) the potential problems and risks inherent in a mature producing oil field in Kazakstan; and (iii) the limited experience of the Government and Uzenmunaigas in managing a program for the solicitation of external investors. 5.11 Country Contditons. As noted in Chapter 2 of this SAR, Kazakstan has made significant progress in the last year in creating a hospitable and stable commercial environment for investments in the oil and gas sector. While more work needs to be done on the administrative aspects of both the legal and fiscal framework, the direction of reform is both positive and firmly established. The domestic market for crude oil and petroleum products has been liberalized and substantial complementary reforms in the structure of the industry have already been made. However, transport constraints cap the country's oil production potential, limit exports to international markets and render the total level of oil exports volatile. Despite these conditions, foreign investment interest in exploration acreage and in discovered but undeveloped reserves continues to be strong because licenses over such properties are valuable options as long as there is no commitment, over a reasonably long period, to exercise them by investing in field development. However, interest in the actual development of reserves or in investment in developed, producing fields is limited for three reasons: (i) lack of assured markets for large scale production; (ii) investor concerns about regional and Kazakstan macroeconomic
 38 V. The Rehabilitation Program stability and the inability to hedge against this perceived instability without direct access to international markets; and (iii) the problems associated with the management of established producing oil fields. 5.12 Problems Inherent to Mature Field Operations. As the detailed description and analysis of Uzenmunaigas' organization and operations in Chapter 4 of the SAR shows, prospective external investors in mature oil fields face considerable potential risks and uncertainties: First, the organization of oil enterprises is inefficient and not conducive to commercially viable operations. The organization of oil enterprises is based on narrow specialization and division of labor, high degree of integration of all aspects of oil field operations into single enterprises, extensive fragmentation and duplication in the management of operations, and internal financial cross-subsidization of many non-viable activities. The high degree of specialization and the organization of activities into autonomous units along functional lines leads to considerable redundancy of labor as weHl as waste of other resources. The incentive for enterprises to restructure their organization and manpower is low since oil enterprises in Kazakstan currently have no clearly defined mandate or powers to operate as autonomous and commercially-oriented entities. Further, the flexibility to reorganize is severely constrained by the historic and continuing role of oil enterprises as the primary source of employment and financing of social services and amenities in the oil producing regions of the country. Without organizational restructuring to address these problems or to create special purpose organizations without the labor burdens and commercial restrictions of traditional oil enterprises, external investment in mature oil producing enterprises is unlikely to be forthcoming. Second, mature producing oil fields like Uzen have been subjected to operating practices that are significantly different from those pursued in other parts of the world. While the practices are well-known, there is considerable uncertainty about their impact on the condition of the wells and gathering and processing facilities in such fields. In the case of Uzen and many other mature fields, this uncertainty is exacerbated by the lack of a complete history of basic operating information (particularly relating to production from individual wells and the integrity of gathering facilities) and the perceived distortions or unreliability of available operating information. The acquisition of additional information on past operations and their impact on future operating costs and investments is a hurdle not confronted by undeveloped fields in the country or by many developed producing fields in many other oil-producing countries competing for foreign investment resources. This informational penalty is particularly high in the case of fields with a long history of production and complex reservoir characteristics. Third, mature producing fields in Kazakstan have been subject to considerable environmental degradation as a consequence of operating practices, the lack of incentives to enterprises to minimize environmental damage, and the absence of effective compliance mechanisms. The extent of environmental damage as weLl as the degree to which the safety of assets has been compromised by unsound practices is generally undocumented and unknown. There is either no financial provision for restoration of fields or the adequacy of such provision is highly uncertain. The absence of information on existing environmental and occupational safety liabilities poses considerable
 V. The Rehabilitation Programn 39 uncertainties about the allocation of responsibility for the costs of their rectification in the future. 5.13 Solicitation of External Investors. Given their relatively lesser attractiveness as investment targets, mature oil producing assets and operations emerging from an operating and business environment typical of those faced by Uzen need substantially stronger promotional efforts than exploration or discovered but undeveloped prospects. A well-structured promotional effort would need to include all of the following key elements: (i) the formulation of a strategy for optimizing the long-term return to the field; (ii) the defmition of the possible bases for extemal participation in the realization of such a strategy; (iii) the identification of the country and field-specific risks entailed in an investment and the development of a strategy for resolving or protecting potential investors against them; (iv) the selection, collection, packaging and dissemination of information on the field and its operation in a way that is useful to potential investors; and (v) the evaluation of the capacity of prospective investors to fulfill their technical and financial obligation under any operating agreement entered into with the Government and Uzenmunaigas. 5.14 Although the Govemment and Uzenmunaigas have long been active in promoting Uzen to potential foreign operators and investors, these efforts have not been guided by a well-defined strategy and have been largely unsuccessful: (a) a number of attractive candidates have been deterred from further evaluation of the field because of perceived problems with the quality of data made available on the field or the perceived country and specific investment risks; (b) a large number of agreements, some with potentially conflicting terms, have been entered into without adequate assessment of the possible impact of their terms on the optimal exploitation of the field's reservoir and the financial returns to Uzenmunaigas; this has also deterred or may serve to deter some potential operators concemed about the limited prospects under such conditions for rational management of the field as a whole; and (c) a substantial amount of management time has been devoted to seeking to secure agreements with parties with little prospect of being able to contribute to the effective implementation of a comprehensive rehabilitation program. PROJECT OBJECTIVES 6.1 The main objectives of the project are to: (i) help reduce the rate of decline in oil production and generate resources for reinvestment in the Uzen field's operations; (ii) promote the reorganization of Uzenmunaigas into commercially viable corporate units and its/their privatization; (iii) assist Uzenmunaigas in assessing the impact of past operating practices on the present condition of the reservoirs, wells and the environment of the field; (iv) contribute to the remediation of past environmental damage to the field and to the strengthening of Uzenmunaigas' environmental monitoring and management systems and capacity; and (v) train Uzenmunaigas' staff in modem oil field operating practices and strengthen the organization's capacity to manage the implementation of the rehabilitation program and oil field operations. 6.2 Key indicators of the achievement of the project objectives, as well as specific interim operating and financial performance targets which will serve as milestones towards the realization of the objectives, are shown at Annex 6.13. B. THE RELATIONSHIP OF THE PROJECT TO THE REHABILITATION PROGRAM 6.3 The proposed program for the restoration of the production capacity of the Uzen field consists of an integrated package of measures covering: (i) a rehabilitation investment program; (ii) a program of restructuring, reorganization and privatization of Uzenmunaigas; and (iii) a program for the attraction of strategic equity investors in Uzenmunaigas' oil-producing operations. The proposed project will continue the Bank's role in assisting the Government to design and implement these programs. Additional Bank support in the implementation of the above package of measures is being provided under the Petroleum Technical Assistance Project and through the selective use of Bank-administered bilateral trust funds. 6.4 The investment components of the project would cover about 12% of the estimated investment cost of the rehabilitation program and will provide early support to Uzenmunaigas in: (i) clarifying the production risks and determining the production potential of the field; and (ii) stemming the rate of production decline and deterioration in the condition of the field. In addition, the project would provide assistance to Uzenmunaigas in developing and implementing the management infrastructure and capability required to operate the field efficiently and commercially. 6.5 The sequencing of the project with other, albeit uncertain, investment activities that may result from the on-going search for private equity investors raises a number of issues about the consistency of possible different approaches to the rehabilitation of the field. These issues have been addressed satisfactorily. In particular, the following actions have been taken: First, Uzenmunaigas, with the assistance of legal and financial consultants, has prepared model agreements and investment strategies to govern the technical and financial basis for the participation of future investors in the rehabilitation of the field. This framework for future investment activities is satisfactory to the Bank and would reduce the risk of

Second, in order to minimize the possibility of conflict with the choices that might be made by future investors in the field, appropriate safeguards have been taken with respect to the choice of technologies and operating practices and the scale, flexibility and timing of investments under the project. Third, to minimize the risk of uneconomic investments under the project, no investment in the field would be undertaken until the production potential of the wells in selected blocks throughout the field has been assessed through a well-structured program of physical testing of a representative sample of wells. Finally, implementation arrangements are consistent with full participation in the management of the field as a whole, including the implementation of the project, by potential equity investors in the field. In particular, the schedule for the organized search for long-term operating partners and the implementation plan for the project are such that potential equity investors are expected to be identified substantially in advance of the completion of a project workover plan and the completion of the final bidding documents for the field processing facilities. The Project 46 (2) Surface Facilities Rehabilitation 6.13 Block 3A has 14 test separators, 5 fluid gathering stations and 2 water injection pump stations and fluid production and water injection flow lines of total length of about 205 km and 20 km respectively. The facilities are extensively deteriorated and lack adequate flow metering and monitoring equipment to effectively manage and control operations. In their present condition, the risk that the facilities would constrain future production from rehabilitated wells is high. Moreover, the deficiencies in control equipment would render it difficult to efficiently manage production from the wells rehabilitated under the project. Finally, the present design and condition of the facilities does not allow for significant reduction of produced water in the field, cannot support recycling back into the water injection system of any separated water and leads to the transport of an unnecessarily large amount of fluid over long distances from the field to the central processing facilities. The project would include the comprehensive rehabilitation of the surface facilities in Block 3A to address these deficiencies. The main elements of the surface facilities rehabilitation are as follows: (i) Replacement of about 340 flowlines of total estimated length of about 205 km (135 km of 3 inch diameter and about 70 km of 4 inch diameter) between production wells and gathering stations. (ii) Relocation of satellite and integration of the existing gathering stations into about 8 stations with test and group separators and associated flow measuring and control equipment. (iii) Replacement of oil/water transfer lines between gathering stations and the existing central processing plant and installation of new produced water transfer lines from the new gathering stations to the water injection station in Block 3A. (iv) Modification of the existing processing plant to establish a dedicated process train for crude oil produced from Block 3A. (v) Installation of a complete water treatment system at the water injection pump stations in Block 3A. (vi) Replacement of the existing water injection pumps, high pressure water injection lines between the water pump station and injection wells with associated flow measurement and control equipment. (vii) Replacement of the high pressure water injection line system between water injection stations and injection wells with associated flow measuring and control equipment. 6.14 All sub-components will embody appropriate provisions for corrosion protection. Sub-components (i) to (iii) and (v) to (vii) above constitute the most critical elements of a possible dedicated and closed-loop system for the processing of produced fluids in the selected block. These subcomponents also represent the least likely elements of such a system to be redundant in the event that Uzenmunaigas continues with the present system of centralized

(3) Environmental Protection and Remediation 6.15 The environmental protection and remediation component of the project is based on the Environmental Protection and Mitigation Plan developed during the Enviromnental Assessment of the project and project appraisal. Physical Investment Implementation Support (1) Well Testing and Logging Services 6.25 The available data on wells performance is limited and unreliable. Most wells in the field are not metered and the reliability of readings from metered wells is low. Similarly, a large proportion of meters at test separators are defective or unreliable. Fluid and oil allocation back to individual wells is highly arbitrary. Well bottom-flowing and shut-in pressures are unknown and water injection volumes in target zones are highly questionable. The lack of reliable data would make programming of workover and re-completion operations difficult. It would also render the assessment of returns on future rehabilitation investments difficult and increase the perceived risk of such investments. The project will provide for the two-stage testing and logging of producer and injector wells. The tests are designed to reduce the risks of the project by allowing a better determination of the production potential of the wells and selected formations in Blocks 3A and other areas of the field and the required scope and cost of workovers. The first stage will entail the procurement of well testing services for the testing of a sample of about 400 producer wells in Block 3A and in adjacent and other selected blocks field-wide. The proposed testing program will use coiled oil tubing units, hot oil trucks and associated equipment to determine, inter alia, current actual well productivity for the sample of wells, the incremental productivity that can be expected after the clean-out and workover of wells and the operational requirements for sustaining future production from the sample wells. The results of the tests would be used as a basis for the formulation of the project workover program. The tests would provide an important additional but incidental benefit: the tests involve the cleaning-out of wells and, in some cases, this would suffice to increase sustainable well production and defer the need for more comprehensive workovers. Details of the proposed testing program are provided in Annex 6.5. During negotiation, agreement was reached with Uzenmunaigas that no well workover would be undertaken under the project prior to the availability of results from the well testing program and the development of a well workover plan based on the results of such a program.

 VII. ECONOMIC EVALUATION A. PROJECT BENEFITS AND COSTS 7.1 The project's main benefit would be a substantial increase in oil production from existing producer wells in the selected project areas. The sources of the anticipated incremental oil production are four-fold: First, the project is expected to lead to an initial increase in fluid production per well, an increase in the oil content per unit of fluid produced and a decrease in the current rate of decline in the oil-to-water ratio per unit of fluid produced. Second, production from selected shut-in wells rendered inoperative due to deferral of services and lack of parts would be restored. Third, the frequency of servicing of wells as a result of wax buildup would be reduced, increasing the time wells are available for production and boosting the capacity of Uzenmunaigas to service wells in general. Fourth, the project would relieve the constraints on wells production resulting from the periodic plugging and frequent leakages in fluid gathering lines and it would contribute to the elimination of the near-term but unpredictable threat of the collapse of the deteriorated field surface facilities and the cessation of oil production. 7.2 Production Assumptions. With the project, fluid production per rehabilitated well is projected to increase by about 61% from 18 cm/day to 29 cm/day accompanied by a reduction in the water-cut (water content per unit.of fluid production) from 75 % to 50%. Under these conditions, average per well oil production would increase from around 5 tons per day to 14 tons per day. Oil production per well is projected to decline at a rate of around 10% per annum thereafter. Based on these projections, total oil production from the project area would amount to 12.3 million toIIs over a 17-year production horizon. For the pre-selected Block 3A, it is estimated that the projected oil production would result in an ultimate recovery of about 30% of the original oil in place in the formations in the block. This level of recovery is consistent with the technically feasible recovery factors projected by independent reservoir engineering consultants. 7.3 Without the project, it is assumed that workovers would be implemented in the selected project areas by external investors. Over the last two years, a number of independent workover contractors and small foreign oil companies have expressed interest in rehabilitating producer wells in the Uzen oil field outside of the investment promotion activities supported by the Bank. The rehabilitation proposals presented to Uzenmunaigas have had a fairly uniform structure viz: the contractors would: (a) have the right to select a block or several blocks in the field to be subject to rehabilitation; (b) hold exclusive rights to perform workovers in such selected blocks; (c) determine the scope of work to be undertaken, subject to Uzenmunaigas' approval; (d) be reimbursed for the cost (including a profit element) of all workover performed on each well irrespective of the success of the work; alternatively, some proposed agreements provide for a guaranteed return on the contractor's investment in the blocks which would be achieved through appropriate transfer pricing to Uzenmunaigas of all oil produced within such blocks; and (e) share in the incremental oil produced beyond a pre-specified production baseline. 7.4 The features of the above investment proposals have important implications for the conduct of workovers. Since the contractors' returns are substantially unrelated to the successful outcome of their work, they would be expected to have: (i) less incentive to maximize fluid and oil production after rehabilitation or to invest in pre-workover wells-screening procedures to increase the probability of success of workovers; and (ii) limited interest in the optimal exploitation of reserves through the life of the reserves in the blocks and a strong tendency to
 66 VII. Economic Evaluation exploitation of reserves through the life of the reserves in the blocks and a strong tendency to maximize short-term production in the cases where the achieved production, post-rehabilitation, is greater than the pre-specified baseline. 7.5 The provisions of the proposals also potentially have both adverse production externalities and distributional consequences: (a) the oil-bearing layers in the Uzen field straddle all the blocks in the field and the management of rehabilitation and production activities in the blocks selected by contractors independently of the management of the parts of the same underlying reservoirs in other areas of the field would lead to sub-optimal exploitation of the field as a whole; and (b) the guaranteed returns to the contractors might be financed out of the cashflow generated in other activities in the field. 7.6 Based on the above, it is projected that in the without-project case, workovers would be characterized by the following attributes: (i) the average failure rate of workovers, i.e the proportion of workovers that would not result in increased post-workover fluid production, would be 25 % compared to 10% in the with-project case; (ii) fluid production in the case of effective workovers would increase by 50% or about 82% of the increase in the with-project case; (iii) the water-cut in immediate post-worker fluid production would remain at the current (pre-workover) average field-wide rate of 73 %; and (iv) the rate of decline in oil production, post-workover, would be reduced to 12% per annum. The projections reflect the incentive structure of the investment proposals extant and the likely absence of any systematic improvements in reservoir management practices under such structure. The potential impact of adverse production externalities is not taken into account. The total oil production in the without-project case under these conditions is projected at 4.3 million tons over a production period of 11 years. 7.7 The total incremental oil production from the project, based on the production profiles with and without the project, is about eight million tons. The projected peak annual incremental oil production is about 0.8 million tons (about 15,000 bbllday) in the fifth year of the project. The projected production profiles and incremental oil production are illustrated in Annex 7.1 and Annex 7.2. 7.8 Oil Price Assumptions. The composition of oil sales for Uzen crude oil sales for the first eight months of 1995 are shown in Annex 7.3. Currently, about 44% of Uzen oil sales are based on the toll-processing of crude oil at the Atyrau refinery with Uzenmunaigas taking delivery of petroleum products for sale to third parties. The balance of Uzen oil sales consist of export sales to other countries of the FSU (22 % of total sales), swaps with Russian producers and traders for equivalent (after transport-cost and quality adjustments) deliveries to the eastern Kazakstan refineries (20%) and export sales to international markets outside the FSU (14%). 7.9 Based on assays performed by the Atyrau refinery, the yield of high-value light prodwcts (gasoline, diesel and kerosene) from Uzen oil processed in the Atyrau refinery is only about 39 %. The balance of refined output consists of low-value heavy fuel oil. Ex-refinery petroleum product prices in all regions of Kazakstan are close to import parity levels. However, the yield structure of refined Uzen crude oil depresses net revenues to about US$40 per ton after processing charges of 30% of the gross value of the petroleum products (Annex 7.4). About 80 % of the net petroleum product yield is bartered by Uzenmunaigas for local operating inputs e.g power purchases, and food.
 VIl. Economic Evaluation 67 7.10 Swap transactions with Russian oil producers are structured on a basis that allows Uzenmunaigas to: (i) toll-process exchanged crude oil at the refineries in Chimkent or Pavlodar; or (ii) sell the received crude oil to the large network of oil traders in the Omsk area in Russia; or (iii) sell the received crude oil directly to the refineries. The appropriate benchmark for valuing swap transactions is the net value to Uzemnunaigas from toll-processing and sale of petroleum products. Based on current ex-refinery prices (excluding VAT), the gross value of the yield of petroleum products per ton of crude oil processed in Chimkent and Pavlodar is US$85 and US$100 respectively. The net value per ton of crude oil after transport charges, crude oil quality adjustments and toll processing fees is US$57 at Chimkent and US$77 per ton at Pavlodar. The audit, performed by a major international accounting fimn, indicates that Uzenmunaigas sold all crude oil received under swap transactions to oil trading intermediaries or the Russian swap party. The effective discount on the netback on product sales incurred by Uzenmunaigas for these direct sales transactions is estimated at 10% for an average (assuming even distribution of sales between the Chimkent and Pavlodar market catchment areas) effective netback of US$60 per ton of swapped crude oil. 7.11 At present, crude oil export sales to the FSU (outside Russia) are mainly to the Ukraine, which accounted for about 75 % of all such sales in the first eight months of 1995. Export prices to the Ukraine over this period varied from US$70 to US$80 per ton at the refinery gate (including VAT levied by Kazakstan). These prices represented a relatively stable fraction of international crude oil prices (fob Novorissiysk) of about 75 %. Based on current export sales prices, the netback at the Kazakstan border from oil exports to the Ukraine, after transport and sales charges, is US$68 per ton. The balance of FSU export sales have been mainly to Belarus. Export sales to Belarus have been at a variable but progressively narrowing price discount to Ukraine sales. Evidence from the latter half of 1995 indicates that the discount has been eliminated. All sales in 1995 to the FSU (outside Russia) have been for cash settlement and the record of payment to the sales intermediary (the Kazakstan state-owned oil trading company, Munai-impex) has been good. 7.12 For exports to international markets, Kazakstan has two major transport channels: (i) through the seaport of Ventspils in Latvia; and (ii) through Novorissiysk. Net sales revenues per barrel of crude oil from the two outlets are similar although transit reliability to Ventspils is lower due to the greater numbers of transiting countries involved. Crude oil exported through Novorissiysk is traded in the Mediterranean with Brent as the marker crude. Crude oil streams from Kazakstan are initially blended at Atyrau and further blended at Samara in Russia with crude oil from other fields in Russia and traded as Ural Export Blend (UEB). UEB suffers a quality discount of about US$4.4 per ton (US$0.6 per bbl) relative to the Brent marker price. Transport and port handling charges to Augusta, Italy (Mediterranean trading point) from Uzen amount to US$22.8 per ton (US$3 per bbl). At the present (mid-October 1995), Brent marker price of US$16.5 per bbl, the current international export-parity price for Uzen crude oil is about US$93 per ton (US$12.7 per bbl). 7.13 At present, virtually all of the available export pipeline transport quota to international markets outside the FSU has been allocated to joint-venture operations or the domestic PAs with substantial foreign debt-service obligations. Until additional export pipeline capacity is developed, Uzenmunaigas would not be able to export significant incremental amounts of oil to international markets outside the FSU. However, there is adequate headroom for exports to regional markets, through swaps or direct deliveries, to accommodate incremental production

In the absence of regulatory pressures to sell or process oil through Atyrau, all incremental production would be expected to be directed to the regional market. 7.14 For the economic evaluation of the benefits of the project, it is assumed that in the counterfactual case, Uzen oil sales continue to be distributed as at present. In the case of the project, it is assumed that sales through Atyrau refinery are equal to the amount channelled to the refinery in the counterfactual case. Under this assignment, sales to Atyrau decline from 40 % of total sales at the beginning of the project to zero (at the cessation of production in the without-project case). Oil sales over and above the amount to Atyrau are allocated equally between swaps and CIS sales. Based on this market distribution and the price of oil in the various markets, the average price of oil in the projections in the project case varies from US$55 per ton at the start of the project to US$64 per ton from the twelfth project year. Oil prices in each of the three markets are maintained at the 1995 level in nominal terms until 2000; thereafter, all prices and input costs are maintained in constant terms. These price assumptions are conservative. To ensure that the benefits to the project are not unduly depressed by involuntary toll-processing of crude oil by Uzenmunaigas at the Atyrau refinery, agreement was reached with the Government during appraisal, that Uzenmunaigas would be free to market its crude oil as it deems to be commercially appropriate. This agreement is in line with current Government policy and was confirmed during negotiations. In addition to the above agreement, which is covenanted under the Loan Agreement, the Government has declared its intention to pass an implementing resolution for the proposed project under which Uzenmunaigas' ability to market its crude oil--domestically and regionally-- would be fully clarified. 7.15 Operating Cost Assumptions. The incremental operating costs under the project are mainly parts and equipment for the maintenance of wells and production facilities, electricity for lifting oil and pumping water and fluid, and chemicals for wax, scale and corrosion inhibition. Kazakstan does not produce oil field equipment, parts and chemicals. These inputs are imported and are evaluated at international prices plus transport costs to Uzen. The foreign currency costs of imported inputs exclude taxes and duties. It is assumed that the future periodic workover and servicing of the wells rehabilitated under the project would be undertaken by independent contractors or by an appropriately structured autonomous division of Uzenmunaigas. The cost of the periodic workover and routine servicing of wells reflect mainly the capital cost of rigs and the cost of replacing equipment and parts in wells. It is estimated that the cost of post- rehabilitation workovers would be equal to about 30 % of the cost of workover of a well under the project. 7.16 Electricity is the main source of domestic operating costs. The north-western region of Kazakstan has a large deficit of power generating capacity, and imports of electricity from Russia account for a significant share of its electricity requirement. The domestic price of electricity in the evaluation reflects the estimated marginal economic cost of power in the region. 7.17 The price of non-tradeable goods and services in Kazakstan is expected to increase significantly in the medium term relative to internationally tradeable goods to correct the substantial undervaluation of the real exchange rate of the tenge. The magnitude and timing of the correction is uncertain. For planning purposes and for the economic and financial projections, it is assumed that local costs will increase at a rate of 15% per annum over the project implementation period relative to increases in foreign costs (of importable goods and
 VII. Economic Evaluation 69 services), which are assumed to move in line with the Bank's projections of increases in the Bank's muv index. The exchange rate is held constant at the current nominal rate. 7.18 The wells to be rehabilitated under the project account for about 12% of the estimated total producer wells in the field. No incremental fixed costs for the operation of the field are assigned to the project. In the economic evaluation, it is assumed that Uzenmunaigas is successful in attracting other external resources for the rehabilitation of the rest of the wells and the infrastructure in the field. Based on the evaluation of the prospects for the field as a whole, production in the rest of the field is likely to cease within the next five years or so unless a concerted rehabilitation program is undertaken. If production in the rest of the field ceases, the project would have to incur the necessary fixed costs of operating the field. No benefit is assigned to the project for the reduction in field-wide operating costs that are likely to arise from some of the management components or restructuring conditions of the project. The implications for the operating costs of the project of lack of success in attracting other sources of external financing for the rehabilitation of the rest of the field are considered in paragraph 7.27 below. 7.19 The operating cost structure of the project (based on the incremental economic costs with the project) is summarized in Annex 7.5. Reflecting the build-up in oil production,total operating costs under the project (excluding field-wide shared costs, depreciation and rehabilitation expenses financed under the project) decrease from US$11.4 per ton (US$1.6 per bbl) in the first project year to a low of US$6.7 per ton (US$0.9 per bbl) in the fourth year of the project. Unit operating costs are subsequently projected to increase markedly thereafter as the ratio of water to oil increases from 50% at the inception of the project to 85% by 2010. However, owing to the large fixed costs of field operations already in place, the average operating cost over the producing life of the project is relatively low at about US$17 per ton (US$2.3 per bbl) on a nominal undiscounted basis or US$14 per ton (US$1.8 per bbl) on a discounted basis (with costs and production discounted at 12%). 7.20 Capital Cost Assumptions. The investment costs used in the economic evaluation are the costs of all project components, net of taxes and duties. In addition, the economic evaluation takes into account the estimated costs of replacing the satellite and gathering stations and flowlines needed to serve a cluster of about 150 wells -- the estimated number of wells outside Block 3A which are to be rehabilitated under the project. The cost of the rehabilitation of surface facilities outside Block 3A is not provided for in the financing of the project. It is expected that such complementary investments to the workovers outside of Block 3A would be financed in subsequent phases of the rehabilitation program. 7.21 In the case of the assumed counterfactual, the investment costs include only the cost of rehabilitating producer wells. In line with the typical feature of the agreements in place, no provision is made for the rehabilitation of the surface infrastructure. The Bank's experience in oil projects in the region indicate that the cost of equipment, parts and services under the type of proposed agreements now seen in Uzemnunaigas (and which were fairly prevalent in the Russian oil industry in the early years of the Bank's involvement) are significantly higher than those received under the Bank's competitive procedures. However, to be conservative, no premium over the Bank's cost estimates are included in the without-project case.

The result of this analysis suggests that the project has a high probability (greater than 95 %) of achieving rates of returns greater than the benchmark for economic viability. 7.27 The impact on the project of a lack of resources to rehabilitate the rest of the field is illustrated in Annex 7.8. If the field were to cease production within five years as projected in Chapter 5 in the case that no rehabilitation investments are undertaken, field-wide fixed and shared costs (i.e labor, transport services, water supply, administrative costs, etc.) would need to be reduced by about 55 % for the project to be able to bear such necessary additional costs of operating the field and still be economically viable. Thus, under very adverse field-wide conditions, the project could still continue to be viable, if adequate restructuring actions are taken. The proposed project would help Uzenmunaigas to strengthen its capacity to restructure and manage its operations to continue to be viable under adverse business conditions. 7.28 Finally, the impact of delays in the implementation of the project has been analyzed. The analysis assumes that the profile of workovers is extended to six years with a one year delay in the start of the program, all other things being equal. This scenario results in an ERR of about 30%. To the extent that Uzenmunaigas would benefit from the technical support in reservoir management and improved production practices that are included in the project during the period of delay, the decline in the ERR is probably overstated. C. PROJECT RISKs 7.29 The major risks faced by the project are: (i) implementation: the risk that project completion may be delayed and the benefits of the project not realized and sustained; (ii) reservoir: the risk that the projected production increases may not be achievable because of the physical properties or condition of the reservoir and wells in the selected project areas; (iii) market and pricing: the risk that a reduced demand in regional markets may cause reduced sales volumes and that oil prices may not be adequate to ensure the project's viability; (iv) financing constraints: the risk that inadequate cash generation in Uzen operations as a whole would lead to inappropriate use of the project's cash flow and inability to replace or maintain key field assets; and (iv) field management policies: the adoption of inappropriate policies for management of the rehabilitation of the field which may limit total oil recovery. 7.30 Implementation Risk. The project management capacity of Uzenmunaigas is weak at this stage and operating and maintenance practices in the Uzen field would need sustained improvements to ensure that the equipment and facilities to be provided under the project are utilized effectively. These weaknesses would be mitigated to some extent by the implementation arrangements and training envisaged under the project. A successful outcome to the on-going search for a long-term operating partner would further mitigate these risks and enhance the sustainability of project benefits beyond the project period. 7.31 Reservoir Risk: The condition of the reservoirs in the field is uncertain and historic wells performance data may be unreliable for a variety of reasons. Nonetheless, the projected increases in future oil production are well within increases achieved in the past under operating conditions similar to those envisaged with the project. The risk that substantial investments
 72 VII. Economic Evaluation would be made in wells that subsequently perform uneconomically is low given the proposed comprehensive program of pre-investment wells testing and analysis. 7.32 Market and Pricing Risk: There is a risk that demand may be weak in regional markets or transport flows may be subject to interruption. These adverse events would be reflected either in lower sales volumes or depressed prices against which Uzenmunaigas may have limited options or capacity to hedge. There is also a risk of erosion in domestic oil prices. The sensitivity analysis suggest that project returns are relatively robust in the face of declines or variations in the price of crude oil and in crude oil production and sales. However, these risks could be further mitigated by strengthening Uzenmunaigas' marketing capacity and diversifying its markets within the transport constraints it faces as well as by implementing, if possible, price hedging strategies. 7.33 FYnancing Constraints: The long-tern sustainability of the project depends on progress made in the rehabilitation of the rest of the field and in commercializing Uzenmunaigas' operations. Without this, there is a significant risk that the resources generated under the project and required for reinvestment to sustain field operations may be devoted to the non-viable activities of Uzemnunaigas. The capacity of Uzenmunaigas to protect against this risk depends on how rapidly progress is made in attracting additional outside financing and in the restructuring of its operation and management. Satisfactory plans and actions are under development or underway to address these issues. These plans and actions are monitorable and would be the subject of on-going review during project implementation. 7.34 Field Management Policies: The investment program for the full rehabilitation of the Uzen field and the proposed Bank-financed project have been designed on the basis that the field would be managed, for operational and investment activities, as a single unit and that all future investment agreements would be entered into on the basis of such a policy. In the absence of adherence to such a policy, the ultimate recovery of oil, the economic viability of a rehabilitation program and the sustainability of the project would be materially and adversely affected. The potential long-term operating partners that have already visited the field to conduct due diligence reviews prior to deciding on participating in the tender of the field under the organized search for private investors financed by the Bank have made it clear that the attraction of the field as an investment target would be significantly diminished if it is not managed as a single unit. There is currently an agreement between Uzenmunaigas and an outside party which provides for significant areas of the field to be rehabilitated outside of a framework for the field as a whole. The Government and Uzenmunaigas have provided adequate assurances that all future investment agreements would be on the basis that the field is managed as a single unit. In addition, through the right of review and approval of work programs provided for under all agreements, Uzenmunaigas can exercise considerable influence over the type and nature of work performed by contractors to ensure that they are consistent with an optimal field-wide approach.

 STAFF APPRAiSAL REPORT REPUBLIC OF KAZAKSTAN UZEN OIL FIELD REHABILITATION PROJECT ANNEX 4.1 GEOLOGY OF THE FIELD BACKGROUND 1. The supergiant Uzen was discovered in the South Mangyshlak region in 1959 and exploitation began in 1965. It is located on the Zhetybay step that comprises the northern slope of the South Mangyshlak trough. The step is characterized by an extremely high density of petroleum discoveries; almost all oil and gas fields of the vast South Mangyzshlak region are concentrated on this prominent structural trend. All of the productive zones occur in Jurassic rocks. Although Lower Cretaceous rock possess good reservoir properties, they are flushed by fresh water and do not contain hydrocarbons. 2. The Uzen field is an anticline with a maximum oil column of 330m at the oil-water contact of 1135m below the ground. Formation dips are gentle and there are no significant faults. The productive reservoirs are Middle to Upper Jurassic sandstones deposited in an alluvial fan environment. The main reservoirs have been sub-divided into Formations MII through XVIII, but each sequence contains several individual sands. The XIII and XIV formations contain more than 60% of the original oil-in-place. (00IP). The sands can be described as fine-grained, angular, and poorly sorted. They are rich in feldspar and lithic rock fragments. Detrital clays and cements (up to 15%) are mainly kaotinite with no swelling clays identified. Typically each formation shows a fining upward sequence with the best sands at the base and the poorer sands at the top. From well logs and well tests, a common oil-water contact across the field at - 1135m below the ground has been interpreted. There were no significant initial gas caps, since the oil is under-saturated with a bubble point of 6500 kPa (65 atm), compared to an initial pressure of 12375 kPa (124 atm) at the oil-water contact. . 3. Fluid Properties: Pressures are hydrostatic (10.9 kPa/m) and the temperature gradient is 4.2C per 100m with an average ground temperature of 14C at 40m. Analysis of original reservoir pressures confirm that all formations were in pressure communication as indicated by the common oil-water contact. This may also mean that the shale/siltstones separating the sands do not form effective seals and could even contribute to some oil production in the long term. Overall, the average fluid properties for all six reservoirs are estimated as follows: Oil Gravity 854 Kg/m' (340 API) GOR 48 m3/m' Initial Oil Formation Volume Factor 1,188 rm3/sm3 Initial Oil Viscosity 3.5 cp initial Oil Compressibility 14 x 10 -7kPa-' Solution Gas Gravity 0.77

 STAFF APPRAISAL REPORT REPUBUC OF KAZAKSTAN UZEN OIL FIELD REHABIUTATION PROJECT ANNEX 4.3 SURFACE PRODUCTION/INFRASTRUCTURE FACILTiTES 1. The surface production facilities are composed of two major systems, i.e. oil processing and water injection (WI) systems. Electric power is supplied from the Akltau power station though a 150 Km high voltage transmission line. In the field, there are 70 oil cluster stations where well fluid is collected and measured, and one central oil processing plant. At present, the degassed and de-watered oil is pumped up at the central plant and transferred to the Uzen-Atyrau pipeline owned by Yuzhnefteprod (or South Pipeline) Company. Uzen oil is mixed with other oils in western Kazakstan making so-called Kazak Blend. 2. Oil Production System. Well fluid from each well is sent to the nearest cluster station which is located at 300 to 500m away from individual oil wells. Where sucker rod pumps are used, the well head flowing pressure is about 5 atm and at the other wells where gas lift is applied, the pressure is maintained at some 20 atm. The well head flowing temperature is around 70C. Two inch flow lines stretch some 2,100 km in total. At the cluster stations, the well fluid is periodically measured per each well for its total liquid flow rate by a two-barrel type two-phase separator. At each cluster station, a direct heater firing on gas is equipped to heat up again the cooled well fluid from 45C to about 70C. The associated gas is segregated in a 50 m' two- phase separator and the gas is mainly used for line heating. The degassed oil is pumped up by several reciprocating pumps and transported to the central processing plant. Twenty (20) inch gathering lines stretch some 800 km. At the central processing plant, the well fluid is first brought in to Free-water Knock-out Drums where produced water content is basically segregated. The oil is next transferred to direct heaters where the oil is heated up from some 40 to 450C to 700C. Just upstream the heaters, de-emulsifier chemical is injected to enhance separation of the produced water from the oil. The nearly dehydrated oil is then sent to the elevated atmospheric separators where the vapor pressure of the oil is lowered to maximum 500 mmHg. The associated gas from the separators is very small in volume and is flared. The produced water is supposed to be recycled and used as a part of WI water. Final separation of the produced water takes place in two 20,000 m' tanks. The dehydrated oil is then shifted to sales tanks with 10,000 ml volume from which sales oil is pumped up to some 40 atm pressure and sent to a 1,020 mm diameter oil pipeline to Guriev. At the central plant, a piping flexibility is provided to heat up first the oil from cluster stations if the arriving temperature is close to the pour point of the oil (about 357). 3. Water Injection System. For the Uzen oil field, sea water from the Caspian Sea is primarily used as injection water'. At present, the sea water intake is provided in Aktau city and 5,000 m3/hr of sea water is transported to Uzen using a total 150 km of 1,020 mm diameter pipeline. There is no water treatment unit nor corrosion protection unit. In the Uzen field, there are 17 high pressure pumping stations where the WI water is pressurized up to between 108 and 142 atm. Although it is not used due to shortage of gas fuel, a direct heater firing on gas is provided downstream of the high pressure pumps at each WI pump station to heat up the water up to 75C. There are a total of 1,434 injection wells. Four (4) inch diameter injection lines stretch about 1,200 km in total. 1. More than 70% of the injection water is sea water.
