 STAFF APPRAiSAL REPORT REPuBLIc OF KAZAKSTAN UZEN OIL FILD REHABITATION PROJECT ANNEX 6.3 SURFACE REHABILITATION COMPONENT: DETAnIED DESCRIPrlON The main elements of the surface facilities rehabilitation are as follows: (a) Replacement of about 340* flowlines between production wells and gathering stations. (b) Relocation of satellites and integration of the existing gathering stations into about 8 stations with test and group separators and associated flow measuring and control equipment. (c) Replacement of oiVwater transfer lines between gathering stations and the existing central processing plant and installation of new produced water transfer lines from the new gathering stations to the water injection station in Block 3A. (d) Modification of the existing processing plant to establish a dedicated process train for crude oil produced from Block 3A. (e) Installation of a complete water treatment system at the water injection pump station in Block 3A. (f) Replacement of the existing water injection pumps, high pressure water injection lines between the water pump station and injection wells with associated flow measurement and control equipment. (g) Replacement of high pressure water injection line system between water injection stations and injection wells with associated flow measuring and control equipment. (h) Corrosion control of all new facilities. Note (*): The actual number of wells and well numbers will be determined during the well testing which will take place in the earliest stage of the whole rehabilitation project. 2. Flowline Systems The flowlines connected to those wells determined as productive by the well testing program will be replaced by new flowlines. The number of such wells are expected about 340 within Block 3A. 2.1 Flowlines The produced oil from each well will be connected to one of eight (8) gathering stations by 88.9 mm (3 in.) individual flowlines. If the total length exceeds 1 Km, use 4 inch pipes. Thermal insulation should be provided so as to avoid wax crystallization.
 Annex 6.3 113 The flowlines will be buried and coated on the outside with anti-corrosive paint. The pipe used is steel pipe, ASTM-A-106 Grade B or API-5L or equivalent or better and designed per ANSI B3 1.4 with minimum 3 mm corrosion allowance and the inside surface is coated for protection from corrosive water. The flowlines are designed to withstand a 6897 kPaG operating pressure which allows considerable cushion for handling oil/water/gas flow interruptions before the oil starts to cool. Alternatively, fiberglass reinforced piping (FRP) could be used. In this case, coating and catholic protection are irrelevant. However, the design importance is endurance against external forces at road crossings including provision of external casing pipes, etc. Valve flanges on a wellhead are tie-ins points at a well site. Pumping liquid and gas are mixed together after these are released from an outlet of a wellhead and flows into an underground flowline. A piping between the tie-in points and the flowline is provided with a check valve on the outlet line. Each flowline is provided with a high-low pressure shut-down valve near each of well heads and a check valve and a block valve at a tie-in to a manifold in a gathering stations. These prevent back flow in the event of a flowline rupture and enable individual flowlines to be isolated without interrupting production from remaining wells. The flowlines are laid under the underground obstacles such as the existing flowlines, water injection lines, cables, etc. The existing replaced flowlines are demolished and transported to as designated area in Uzen after oil inside are purged appropriately. Following installation of each flowline, the line is hydro-statically tested and cleaned before precommissioning the system. The flowlines are then tied-in to the wellhead at each well site and to the manifold in the gathering station. 3. Satellites and Gathering Stations The existing satellite consists of testing manifold and test separator. One well is selected and led to test separator where liquid (oil and water) production rates are measured periodically. Fluid from test separator and other wells by-passed test separator are mixed and fed to group separators in gathering station. Production fluid from wells is separated in gas and liquid by using group separator. Liquid from group separator is measured and pumped to the central processing plant. No measurement is made for gas production. The present function of satellite will be transferred to gathering stations to operate separator in the same place. New test separators and new group separators will be installed in gathering stations with sophisticated measuring and control equipment. The number of gathering stations will be reduced to eight (8) stations' in the two blocks to operate and maintain the stations more efficiently. A maximum of about 50 wells, an average of 42 wells flow to a gathering station. Three manifold, three test separators, one group separator, one gas scrubber (in principle, reuse of the existing vessels with proper rehabilitation), two oil transfer pumps (one stand-by), two produced water transfer pumps (one stand-by), a chemical injection unit and minimum required utility systems will be installed in each gathering station. 3.1 Manifolds Production from each well is led to one of the new three manifolds and fed to one of the new three test separators or to the new group separator. The tentatively identified gathering station numbers are: 1, 7, 12, 13, 52, 54, 55 and 57.
 114 Annex 6.3 3.2 Test Separators These test separators are three phase separators with a minimum 3 minute liquid retention time. The gas is segregated from liquid in the test separator, and the flow is measured before passing to a gas scrubber. The pressure of the test separator is controlled by the pressure control valve that is equipped downstream of the separator on the gas outlet lines. The flow rate of the oil outlet from the test separator is measured. The water content of the oil outlet is analyzed continuously by the analyzer equipped on the line. The flow of the water outlet from the test separator is also measured. The oil and water are mixed together again and led to the group separator. 3.3 Group Separator/Gas Scrubber/Oil Transfer Pump/Production Heater The group separators are three phase separators. The separators are designed based on a minimum 7 minute liquid retention time. The gas is segregated from the liquid in the separator and mixed with gas from the test separator and led to the gas scrubber. This gas rate is measured at the down stream of the gas scrubber. The pressure of the production and the gas scrubber is controlled by the pressure control valve that is equipped downstream of the gas scrubber. The flow rates of oil (with emulsified water) and free water from the group separator are measured. The oil is pumped to the existing processing plant through the new oil transfer line. The rate of transferring the oil is controlled by the flow control valve by the signal of the group separator's liquid level. Each group station has two 100% pumps, one running and one stand-by. The oil is heated up by a direct fired type production heater just before entering the oil/water transfer line. The free water produced from the group separator is transferred to the new water treatment unit at the water injection pump station in Block 3A. Each group station has two 100% pumps, one running and one stand-by. 3.4 Chemical Injection A corrosion-cum scale inhibitor injection package is provided at each gathering station. This package injects inhibitor at maximum dosing rate of 100 ppm2 based on producing water and continues to inject for one week without any additional supply of inhibitor. 3.5 Utilities All the electric, control and monitoring systems, and an instrument air package required for operations of each gathering station will be installed. The fuel gas for the production heaters is introduced from the gas scrubbers, and necessary systems are to be installed. If necessary, gas supply lines are extended from the existing gas distribution. 3.6 Buildings One control building with a workshop/storage will be constructed in each gathering station. 2 The rate is subject to confirmation by the Contractor.
 Annex 6.3 115 3.7 Location and Number of Gathering Station and wells Approximately eight (8) gathering stations are assumed. (See the footnote of Paragraph 3.3.) An average of 42 wells will be connected to each station. The final locations of the new gathering stations shall be determined during the detailed design phase. 4. Oil Transfer Lines, Produced Water Transfer Lines and Gas Lines 4.1 Oil Transfer Lines The oil separated from gas and free water at the group separator in each gathering station is pumped by the oil transfer pump through a pipeline to the existing processing plant. The oil transfer lines are buried and coated on the outside with anti-corrosion paint. The pipe used is steel pipe, ASTM-A-106 Grade B or API-5L or equivalent or better and is to be designed per ANSI B31.4 with minimum 3 mm corrosion allowance. The pipelines withstand a 6897 kPaG operating pressure which provides allowance for handling oil flow interruptions before the oil starts to cool. Alternatively, fiberglass reinforced piping (FRP) could be used. In this case, coating and cathodic protection are irrelevant. However, the design should consider endurance against external forces at road crossings including provision of external casing pipes, etc. 4.2 Produced Water Transfer Lines The free water segregated from the group separators will be transferred to the water treatment plant at the water injection pump station in Block 3A by Produced Water Transfer Pumps at the gathering stations. The water transfer lines are buried and coated on the outside with anti-corrosion paint. The pipe used is steel pipe, ASTM-A-106 Grade B or API-5L or equivalent or better and is to be designed per ANSI B31.4 with minimum 3 mm corrosion allowance. Alternatively, fiberglass reinforced piping (FRP) could be used. In this case, coating and cathodic protection are irrelevant. However, the design should consider endurance against external forces at road crossings including provision of external casing pipes, etc. 4.3 Gas Lines The gas segregated at the group separator in each gathering station is first used as fuel for the oil heaters at the gathering stations. If any surplus, the gas is transferred to the existing pipelines to the existing processing plant. 5. Modification of Existing Processing Plant 5.1 Process Train A dedicated process train to treat the crude oil from Block 3A will be installed. The train will consist of: one Inlet Heater, one Free Water Knock-out Drum, one Demulsifier Chemical Injection Unit, two Oil Feed Pumps (one stand-by) and one second stage separator.
 116 Annex 6.3 Although piping isolation is made from other trains, it is intended to reuse the existing facilities as far as practical. Subject to bidders' evaluation, the shell for the Inlet Heater and the vessel of the second stage separator could be reuse of the existing units. 5.2 Utilities All the electric, control and monitoring systems, and an instrument air package required for operations will be installed. If necessary, a gas supply line would be extended from the existing gas distribution to the Inlet Heater. 5.3 Buildings Basically, the space of the existing buildings will be used and will be renovated as required. 6. Water Injection Station 6.1 Produced Water Treatment Plant The produced water treatment plant to produce injection water will be installed at the water injection pump station in Block 3A, including utilities for both the gas blanket system and the water treatment package. It is assumed that the produced water treatment system consists of: one Gas Floatator (which removes oil particles); one Settling Tank, two Water Feed Pumps (one stand-by); one set of Sand Filter Unit with back washing; one Chemical Injection Unit (which will dose such chemicals as scale inhibitor, corrosion inhibitor, oxygen scavenger and biocide); and one gas stripping type Deaerator. At the outlet of the water heater down stream of the water injection pumps, a set of cartridge type Fine Filter will be provided. The requirement for the water treatment package shall be as follows: Treatment Rate 4500 m3/d Stream Factor 24 hours and 365 days operation Output Quality pH - 7 to 8 Solid - less than 2 mg/I Oxygen - 0.5 mg/l Minimum Pressure at Water Stations 100 kPaG The design and operating pressures need to be confirmed by the CONTRACTOR considering the conditions of the existing facilities.
 Annex 6.3 117 The input quality of the produced water is assumed as follows: pH 5.0 Specific Gravity 1.11 gm/cm Solid 40 mg/i Oxygen 1.0 mg/l Oil Content 1,000 ppm 6.2 Water Injection Pumps One water injection station will be constructed in Block 3A to inject water at the maximum requirement of 4,500 m3/day. Two water injection pumps with a capacity of 200 m3/h at suction pressure of 59 kPaG and discharge pressure of 13790 kPaG are assumed. The number includes one stand-by pump. The injection water is heated by a water heater up to 60 centigrade and distributed to the water injection lines. 6.3 Utilities All the electric, control and monitoring systems, and an instrument air package required for operations will be installed. A gas supply lines are extended from the existing gas distribution. 6.4 Buildings One control building with a workshop/storage will be constructed in each gathering station. 7. High Pressure Water Injection Systems There will be some 60 active injection wells in Block 3A. Injection water shall be fed from the water injection station to these injection wells via headers and individual high pressure injection lines. The existing high pressure water injection lines are severely corroded. The complete replacement of the high pressure water injection is required in Block 3A. 7.1 High Pressure Water Injection Lines The high pressure water injection lines are buried and coated on the outside with anti- corrosion paint. The pipe used is steel pipe, ASTM-A-106 Grade B or API-5L equivalent or better and is to be designed per ANSI B31.4 with minimum of 3 mm corrosion allowance. The pipes are buried and cathodic protection is provided. A flow meter and a choke valve (which will adjust the injection pressure) are required at upstream of each injection well. Alternatively, fiberglass reinforced piping (FRP) could be used. In this case, coating and cathodic protection are irrelevant. However, the design should consider endurance against external forces at road crossings including provision of external casing pipes, etc.

The objective of the assignment will be establishment of a comprehensive database of existing environmental conditions in the Block 3A in order to do the following: (a) provide baseline data against which both positive and possible negative environmental impacts of the project, including mitigation and remediation measures, will be recorded; (b) develop audit methodology which could be replicated in other parts of the field; and (c) provide initial input into future Uzenmunaigas environmental information and management system. STUDY AREA 2. The study area for the environmental audit is Block 3A of the Uzen field, encompassing an area of about 7.5 square kilometers. It contains about 370 production wells, about 100 water flood injection wells as well as associated gathering lines, field processing facilities, water injection facilities, field worker housing, access roads and pipelines to the central field processing facility. The terrain is generally flat with few remains of the original desert vegetation. The area has very disturbed soil and vegetation cover with extensive areas subject to disturbance from vehicle traffic and production activity and areas containing pits of oil/sludge, as well as scrap metal and other oil field wastes. SCOPE OF WORK 3. Under the assignment, the consultants will collect and store data related to both sources of pollution and their impacts on air, water and soil quality, flora, fauna, and human health and safety. In particular, the consultants will accurately locate and estimate the (a) quality and quantity of hydrocarbon contaminated soil; (b) oil/sludge pits; and (c) nature of the scrap metal and other oil field wastes. The consultants will also map the distribution and types of vegetation cover and the location and types of land disturbances within Block IIA. The consultants should design this data collection in relation to the location of the production and injection wells, gathering system, field processing facilities as well as the main access roads. 4. The consultants will measure the levels of radio-activity associated with oil field production equipment and with oil/sludge pits on Block 3A.

The consultants will summarize results of the field work in a draft report, supported by relevant maps, diagrams, tables and other necessary graphic supplements. Upon incorporation of comments received from the agencies mentioned in above. the consultants will prepare of the final report in English and Russian. CONSULTANTS EXPERIENCE 8.  STAFF APPRAISAL REPORT REPUBLIC OF KAZAKSTAN UZEN OIL FIELD REHABILITATION PROJECT ANNEX 6.5 WELLS TESTING PROGRAM 1. Oil and gas production operators world wide depend on the services of Coiled Tubing Unit (CTU) contractors using "state of the art" technology to service and revitalize previously uneconomical oil and gas producing wells, thus obtaining maximum production efficiency from their existing wells. 2. The proven workover method which has been used for over twenty-five (25) years by the oil production industry to clean out and repair their wells has been with the use of coiled tubing units. These units have been used effectively, without having to pull the tubing, nor have they caused any damage to the tubing, casing or liner in the performance of the following services: (a) sand washing from the bottom of the well; (b) bottomhole fluid displacement, for well treatment; (c) paraffin removal by mechanical methods and by the application of chemicals for paraffin suppression, or heat; (d) spotting mud clean out acids across perforated interval, for well stimulation; (e) unloading heavy drilling fluids that are in wells, after their completion, with lighter fluids to place same on production for flow testing or into commercial production; (f) through tubing fishing operations. 3. In addition, recent technological developments have allowed oil and gas operators to revitalize old wells by drilling out, from the existing wells which have depleted the nearby surrounding reservoir, at a very high angle of deviation, and in some cases, horizontally, in an attempt to reach out to produced additional oil or gas from zones which have not produced any of its oil or gas, due to existing permeability barriers within the reservoir. 4. The use of coiled tubing units permits oil and gas operators to eliminate the use of expensive workover rigs to clean out wells for testing, particularly in wells where an operator is not fully knowledgeable of the existing well conditions nor its eventual productive capacity. 5. Since the coiled tubing operations are performed on wells without the need to kill it, the following are the most significant advantages in using this technology: (a) elimination of formation damage, since bullheading of kill fluids into the reservoir is not necessary; (b) reducing the time to ascertain the well workover/repair program that will eventually need to be executed in the well; (c) a very high success ratio in their operations; (d) low workover equipment cost; and, (e) reduced well maintenance cost.
 Annex 6.5 123 6. In view of the above, it is recommended that a well testing program. be instituted in the Uzen Oil Field in accordance with the procedure outlined below: OBJECTIVE 7. The objective for testing some 400 Uzen Oil Field wells in Block 3A, using a coiled tubing unit, a well test separator, a hot oil truck and other associated equipment is to reduce the project risk by determining and establishing: (a) the ranking of the wells for their eventual workover in Block 3A of the Uzen Oil Field and other selected blocks which will be part of the Bank project; (b) actual well productivity; (c) incremental productivity which can be successfully maintained by the wells, after their clean out and workover; (d) workover program to be designed for each well; and (e) operational requirements which need to be implemented by the operator to assure long term project sustainability. SCOPE OF WORK 8. After agreement on the selection of the wells to be tested for their productivity, a work schedule needs to be established. Early selection of the Coiled Tubing Unit Contractor will permit the contractor to muster and mobilize the necessary resources, equipment, materials and technicians to effectively perform the services required. 9. Prior to commencing operations, it will be necessary for the Uzen Oil Field Operator to (i) for those wells which are on production: the operator must prepare the wells by pulling the sucker rods, pump. and standing valve (in wells so equipped and leaving the wells without mechanical obstructions (tool traps,and other obstructions such as the standing valve in those wells where the pump barrel is part of the production string), thus allowing the testing contractor to run the coiled tubing down to the well's TD (total depth); (ii) for those wells which are not on production and have no down hole equipment or mechanical obstruction: the well testing contractor can proceed to rig-up at any time. 10. The following is a brief detail of the operations, subject to confirmation, which will be required from the CTU contractor: (a) Rig up on well, remove pumping stuffing box and nipple up CTU blowout preventors on wellhead. (b) Run in the hole to the TD of each well with CTU while circulating "hot oil" at a rate of at least half (1/2) barrel per minute. (c) Clean out bottom fines and sand which has accumulated below the perforated interval, if necessary. (d) Circulate the well with "hot oil" for at least ten (10) or twelve (12) complete well volumes, depending on well productivity. (e) Circulated fluid together with the produced fluids from the well will be flowed through a portable three phase separator with a design capacity of some 500 to 750 barrel/day and working pressure not to exceed 750 psi.
 124 Annex 6.5 (f) Fluids from the separator will be measured and discharged as follows: * The separated oil will be discharged into a trip tank for confirmation of incremental production, where it will be recycled into the heating unit (hot oil truck) and used as part of the working fluid in the process. ** The separated water will be collected in a separate tank and disposed of in an environmentally acceptable manner. It is suggested, at this time, that disposal of the produced water be made by trucking fluid to the nearest salt water injection station for disposal. *** The liberated separator gas will be flared, if necessary. (g) Incremental oil accumulated and measured in the trip tank and not used as part of the working fluid will be transferred to existing production facilities through the well's flowline. (h) Upon completion of test program, all incremental oil and working oil can be disposed of by pumping into existing well's flowlines. (i) Pull CTU out of hole, rig down blowout preventor and nipple up well pumping stuffing box and release the well. NOTE: Due to the relative shallow depth of the Uzen Oil Field wells (less than 1500 meters), and the small diameter of the production casing, (5 1/2" OD), it is estimated that the volume of oilfor workingfluid to be circulated to be around 20 barrels, including the volume of oil in the "hot oil truck". Most wells in the field are equipped with plunger pumps set in 2 3/8" tubing run down to around 1200 meters well depth. EQuIPMENT REQUIREMENTS 11. A list of equipment which is expected to be used, subject to confirmation by the contractor, is the following: (a) Coiled Tubing Unit equipped with not less that 8000 feet of 1" or 1 1/4" tubing; (b) High pressure circulating pump, with a capacity of pumping no less than 25 gallons per minute at 2000 psi; (c) Blow out preventor; (d) Injection head and associated equipment; (e) Two trip tanks or equivalent, one for oil and the other for produced water; (f) Hot oil truck with minimum capacity of raising the temperature of oil to at least 100 degrees C and maintaining that temperature during the circulation of volume of some 20 barrels of oil in an hour; (g) 3 phase separator with a capacity to effectively separate about 500 barrels of fluid per day and a working pressure not above 700 psi.; (h) All associated piping and manifolding; and (i) Chemical injection pumps for injection of paraffin suppressing chemicals or foaming agents in order to reduce the bottomhole pressure, if necessary.

 STAFF APPRAISAL REPORT REPUBLIC OF KAZAKSTAN UZEN OIL FIELD REHABILTATION PROJECT ANNEX 7.7 RISK ANALYSIS: MONTE CARLO SIMULATION OF OIL PIuCES 1. The economic evaluation in the main text has been performed based on a constant nominal oil price (adjusted after Year 2000 to drift implicitly in line with "international" inflation). Given the observed pattem of oil prices, this assumption is convenient but clearly not very realistic. However, the standard alternative approach of assuming a linear trend growth in oil prices is equally unrealistic and less conservative. 2. To assess the impact on the economics of the project of a more realistic price pattern for crude oil, a Monte Carlo simulation of oil prices was performed based on the following assumptions: (a) the international (Brent marker) price of crude oil follows geometric Brownian motion with an assumed drift rate of four (4) percent per annum and a standard deviation of 15 percent per annum. The assumed mean annual rate of growth in oil prices is consistent with current consensus projections of the medium-term rate of growth in crude oil prices and EBRD mral oil price projections. Historic medium term estimates of the volatility of crude oil prices vary from 15 to 25 percent per annum. The oil price is modelled by the following equation: oP+ lI = OP x e[(,u - % a.) X a e (a xx d;J] where OP = oil price 1f = drift rate of oil price at = time between period t and period (t + 1) r = standard deviation of oil price dz = a drawing from a standard normal distribution with mean of zero and standard deviation of one; (b) the oil price at the start of the period is assumed at US$120.5 per ton and is revised monthly; (c) there is a fixed proportional relationship between the international oil price and domestic and regional export oil prices based on the current ratio of such prices; and (d) oil transport costs to international markets (for sales to international markets) remain constant in nominal terms at the current (October 1995) level. 3. The Monte Carlo simulation was implemented through random drawings from a standard normal distribution to generate a price path for oil through the 17-year life of the project. Ten thousand iterations of a price path for oil were run.
 Annex 7.7 159 4. The distribution of the net present value of the project based on the result of this simulation is illustrated in the attached graphs. The results indicate that the project expected returns are robust based on a plausible characterization of the price of crude oil. The mean of the NPV (at 12%) of the project is US$177 million. The probability of a negative NPV is about 5 percent. Sensitivity analyses indicate that the NPV increases by about 0.12 standard deviations for every unit increase in the standard deviation of the price of oil. 5. The Monte Carlo simulation of oil prices has also been extended to gain an insight into the cost of hedging against adverse price developments while benefitting from favorable ones, i.e. avoiding oil price-induced unfavorable NPV outcomes, other things being equal. 6. One way of hedging against adverse oil price developments is to purchase an option to sell oil at an average of oil prices over any given year that is no less than a specified level. For example, a series of options to sell oil (in any given year through the life of the project) at an average price that is equivalent to the well head prices that are projected in the economic evaluation (Chapter 7) would, other things being equal, ensure that a minimum ERR of 38% would be achieved. Average rate options of the type discussed above (so-called Asian options) are widely available in international financial markets. 7. For illustrative purposes, the value of an Asian put option has been assessed. Using the same price formation assumption (geometric Brownian motion) as above, the cost of an Asian put option to lock in an average implicit international oil price of no less than US$120.5 per ton over one year was estimated. In line with standard option valuation procedures, the oil price was assumed to grow at the estimated one-year risk-free rate (6% per annum) adjusted for a convenience yield (estimated from crude oil futures prices on the International Petroleum Exchange in January 1996-') of 8% per annum . The discounted pay-off from a put option at the end of the year was calculated based on the difference between the average oil price over the year and the exercise price of US$120.5 per ton. The fair price of an option was derived as the arithmetic mean of the discounted pay-offs after 10,000 iterations for three different degrees of volatility. The results of the simulations are summarized below: Value of Value of Option as Volatility Average Put Option Proportion of Opening ($/ton) International Oil Price 15% $ 7.0 5.8% 20% $ 8.3 6.9% 25% $ 9.5 7.9% Given the well head price, Uzemnunaigas, in principle, would need to purchase about one option (to sell a ton of oil at the assumed exercise average price) for every two tons of sales to hedge against a decline in its projected revenue for the illustrated year. 1. Both the convenience yield and the volatility of crude oil prices are subject to changes over any given period; for simplicity, they are assumed to be constant in the analysis.

 STAFF APPRAISAL REPORT REPUBLIC OF KAZAKSTAN UZEN OIL FIELD REHABILITATION PROJECT ANNEX 8.3 ASSUMPTIONS USED IN THE FINANCIAL EVALUATION The following assumptions are the basis for the projections used in the financial evaluations in Chapter 5 and Chapter 8. The assumptions are consistent with those used for the economic analysis (Chapter 7). 1. Monetary Unit: US Dollars. 2. Exchange Rate: All investments are denominated in US dollars. Historic operating costs and monetary working capital items denominated in tenge have been converted at the average US$:Tenge exchange rates for the relevant period. Other balance sheet items and liabilities have been translated at end of period US$:Tenge rate. All projections are on the basis of a nominal exchange rate of US$1 = Tenge 63. 3. Inflation Indices: Cost estimates are based on 1995 prices. Prices of imported and importable goods and services purchased by Uzenmunaigas are escalated at the Bank's muv index; the cost of international non-tradeable local goods and services are escalated at an average annual rate of 15% over the project implementation period. The projections are in constant (2000) US dollars. 4. Oil Production: The bases for the production profiles, with and without the project, are elaborated in the economic evaluation (Chapter 7) and in the analysis of the rehabilitation program (Chapter 5). The wells workover profiles and the production profiles for the full rehabilitation of the field and for the project are shown explicitly in Annexes 5.1. 5. Oil Prices: The bases for the oil prices used in the economic and financial analysis are detailed in the economic evaluation (Chapter 5) and in the supporting annexes. No price escalation is applied to the oil prices. Export prices to the CIS include VAT; all other prices are net of VAT (see tax assumptions below). 6. Operating Inputs: Electricity requirements are based on the calculated power requirements of: (i) pumping producer wells; (ii) water injections pumps; (iii) pumping and process requirements for the proposed new fluid processing facilities; (iv) historic electricity requirements per unit fluid processed; and (v) an allowance for general electricity use based on historic ratios (in the case of the projections of the performance of the field as a whole. The cost of power is projected at US$0.04 cents (excluding VAT) per kilowatt-hr in the base year. 7. Water: Water requirements for flooding are a non-incremental cost; the cost of water is estimated at US$0.07 (excluding VAT) per 1000 cubic meters in the base year based on the estimated annual equivalent cost of replacement of the existing water line; water requirements for the field are assumed at 2x fluid production levels.
 Annex 8.3 171 8. Chemicals: The following chemical usage rates and prices are assumed in the case of the project and for rehabilitation of the field as a whole: Water Treatment Chemicals Scale Inhibitor: 1 bbl/100,00 water ( US$800/bbl Corrosion Inhibitor: 1 bbl/I00,000 water @ US$1 100/bbl Oxygen Scavanger: I bbl/100,000 water @ US$1300/bbl Biocide: 1 bbl/100,000 water @ US$1800/bbl Oil Production Chemicals Corrosion Inhibitor: 1 bbl/I00,000 fluid @ US$1 100/bbl Scale Inhibitor: 1 bbl/100,000 fluid @ US$800/bbl De-Emulsifier: 1 bbl/100,000 fluid @ US$800/bbl Wax Suppressant: 4 bbl/100,000 fluid @ US$800/bbl In the without project case, only de-emulsifiers are used at the historic rate per unit fluid production. 9. Rehabilitation Workovers: Rehabilitation workovers in all financial projections are expensed as incurred. Rehabilitation workovers are projected to take 6 days per well to perform at a base cost (including logging and completion services, workovers rigs services and materials and parts) of US$138,000 per producer well. 10. Routine Services: The need for routine services in the without project case is assumed to follow the historic rate of two (six monthly) services per active producing well per annum. Services are estimated to require 4.5 days per well at a cost of US$2,600 per well. With the project and with full field rehabilitation, the need for services is projected to decline to once per year per active producing well. Routine workovers are assumed not to be performed in the without project or the without- full field rehabilitation case. In the project case, routine workovers are performed on a five-year cycle at a projected base cost of US$32,400 per well. Labor requirements are not considered incremental. Labor costs in the with-field and without-field-rehabilitation are based on the current estimated payroll costs for the oil producing operations. 11. Transport Losses & Owvn Use: These are based on the recent historic rate of 7% of oil transported by pipeline. 12. Oil Sales: Oil sales are based on production, net of an inventory requirement of 5% of production, and less transport losses and own-use. The distribution of sales for the financial evaluation of the project is based on the composition of sales in the economic evaluation. The basis for the assignment of sales is elaborated in the economic evaluation (Chapter 7).
 172 Annex 8.3 For the analysis of the rehabilitation program for the field as a whole, inventory requirements and losses are as above. Prices are also as at above. The distribution of sales in the analysis of the rehabilitation program is based on the assumption that, in the case of the rehabilitation of the field, sales to Atyrau refinery are equal to the sales levels without rehabilitation and the balance of sales is distributed on a 50/50 basis between CIS sales and swaps with Russian producers. In the without-full field rehabilitation case, 40% of sales are assigned to the Atyrau refinery in line with current market shares. 13. Accounts Receivable: Accounts receivable are assumed to be equal to 40 days of annual sales in all financial projections. 14. Accounts Payable: Accounts payable are assumed to be equal to 30 days of annual operating expenses (excluding rehabilitation expenses and, where applicable, labor costs) in all financial projections. 15. Loan Interest: For purposes of the projections, interest on the on-lent amount is assumed to be at a Bank loan rate of 6.98% plus a margin of 2%. The on-lending maturity is 12 years, including a grace period of four (4) years. No adjustment is made in the debt-service computations for possible gearing effects -- the relative impact of inflation on the value of debt relative to its impact on the cash generation of the project. In the financial projections for the rehabilitation of the field as a whole, it is assumed that all investments are financed with equity. 16. Tax Assumptions: The tax assumptions are as follows: Geological Levy: It is assumed that Uzenmunaigas' oil operations are subject to the geological levy (8% of revenues) and that the application of a future royalty regime to replace this levy is at a comparable average rate. Currently, the average royalty rates applicable to negotiated agreements for oil investments with similar incremental production as in the project are, in general, substantially lower than the rate applied under the levy. Rental Payments: Uzenneft was exempt from rental payments from the inception of the tax to 1993. It was subject to the tax in 1994 at a rate of 2% of oil revenues. However, for the financial evaluation, no additional (excess) profit taxes (including rental payments) are assumed to be applied on the project's incremental contributions to Uzenmunaigas' profits. Value-Added Tax: The prevailing standard rate of VAT is 20%. No VAT is applied against oil sales through Atyrau refinery since the transaction is structured as a sale of oil and purchase of petroleum products with offsetting VAT liabilities for both the refinery and Uzenmunaigas. It is assumed that swap transactions with Russian oil producers are structured in a similarly offsetting basis. VAT on inputs are fully creditable against VAT on CIS sales. However, excess credit of VAT on operating inputs are assumed not to be credited against the VAT liability on oil sales outside the project, carried forward or reimbursed. This is a conservative treatment. For capital expenditures (excluding expended project investment expenditures), it is assumed that no net VAT liability a.-.ses.
 Annex 8.3 173 Depreciation Tax Shields: Although the depreciation schedules specified in the General Tax Code imply applicable tax depreciation lives of between eight and ten years for classes of fixed assets to be procured under the project, a shorter life of five years is used in the analysis. This reflects the thrust of the underlying analytical work for petroleum tax reform in Kazakstan that the applicable tax depreciation rules for petroleum operations may need to be adjusted to provide a more competitive incentive for oil investments. Tax Accounting: Specific tax accounting rules for oil operations are expected to be detailed in the petroleum tax code. For purposes of the financial analysis, all workover costs are expended in the year in which they are incurred. It is assumed that in the computation of incremental taxable income, incremental losses or profits attributable to the project are not offset by profits or losses from other Uzenmunaigas activities.

doc.repnme: Kazakstan - Uzen Oil Field Rehabilitation Project
doc.abstracts: The main objectives of the Uzen Oil Field Rehabilitation Project are to: 1) help reduce the rate of decline in oil production and generate resources for reinvestment in the Uzen field's operations; 2) promote the reorganization of Uzenmunaigas into commercially viable corporate units and its/their privatization; 3) assist Uzenmunaigas in assessing the impact of past operating practices on the present condition of the reservoirs, wells and the environment of the field; 4) contribute to the remediation of past environmental damage to the field and to the strengthening of Uzenmunaigas' environmental monitoring and management systems and capacity; and 5) train Uzenmunaigas' staff in modern oil field operating practices and strengthen the organization's capacity to manage the implementation of the rehabilitation program and oil field operations. The project consists of the following components: 1) physical investments including subsurface rehabilitation (provision of equipment, spare parts and chemicals), surface facilities rehabilitation and environmental protection and remediation; 2) physical investment implementation support comprising well testing and logging services, contract workover services and consulting services; and 3) organizational development support involving the strengthening of Uzenmunaigas management through improvements in its financial and operating information systems and the improvement of its financial management and accounting practices and systems.
